When its head was bitten, toxins entered\nSlowpoke’s head and unlocked an extraordinary\npower.
It has incredible intellect and intuition. Whatever\nthe situation, it remains calm and collected.
This Pokémon startles people in the middle of\nthe night. It gathers fear as its energy.

It likes to make its shell thicker by adding layers\nof tree bark. The additional weight doesn’t\nbother it.

It can make most any Pokémon run away\nby opening its big mouth to reveal its\nthick fangs.

With its herculean powers, it can easily throw\naround an object that is 100 times its own\nweight.
This cunning Pokémon hides under the cover of\ndarkness, waiting to attack its prey.

This artificial Pokémon evolved thanks to cutting-\nedge science. It sometimes displays behavior that\nis not in its programming.

This earnest Pokémon battles all sorts of\nopponents, searching for the fighting style\nthat suits it best.

Born deep underground, this Pokémon becomes\na pupa after eating enough dirt to make a\nmountain.

A rough customer that wildly flails its giant\nclaws. It is said to be extremely hard to raise.

A pair may be seen rubbing their cheek pouches\ntogether in an effort to share stored electricity.
It spins its two tails like a screw to propel itself\nthrough water. The tails also slice clinging\nseaweed.
It inflates its flotation sac, keeping its face above\nwater in order to watch for prey movement.
With its flotation sac inflated, it can carry people\non its back. It deflates the sac before it dives.
It is a common sight around fishing ports. It is\nknown to rescue people and help fishers carry\nwhat they caught.
It used to have a shell on its back long ago.\nThis species is closely related to Pokémon\nlike Shellder.
It oozes a purple fluid to deter enemies.\nApparently, there are more West Sea Shellos\nnow than there were in the past.
Its whole body is sticky with mucus. In the past,\nthis form of Gastrodon was by far the more\nnumerous one.
It appears on beaches where the waters are\nshallow. Once it catches prey, it will slowly melt\nthem with its mucus before slurping them up.
They live on large trees. They are said to\ncommunicate by connecting their tails to\nthose of others.
Split into two, the tails are so adept at handling\nand doing things that Ambipom rarely uses its\nhands.
It is whispered that any child who mistakes\nDrifloon for a balloon and holds on to it could\nwind up missing.
Because of the way it floats aimlessly, an old\nfolktale calls it a “signpost for wandering spirits.”
It can generate and release gas within its body.\nThat’s how it can control the altitude of its drift.
They carry people and Pokémon, but the\nwind can catch them, so there can’t be a\nfixed destination.
Its cry sounds like an incantation. It is said the\ncry may rarely be imbued with happiness-giving\npower.
Its cries sound like incantations to torment the\nfoe. It appears where you least expect it.
It is merciless by nature. It is said\nthat it never forgives the mistakes\nof its Murkrow followers.
A single cry from this nocturnal\nPokémon, and more than 100 of\nits Murkrow cronies will assemble.
There is an orb inside its mouth. When it hops,\nthe orb bounces all over and makes a ringing\nsound.
It emits high-frequency cries that people can’t\nhear. Once it starts, it can cry for an awfully\nlong time.
It sprays a foul fluid from its rear. Its stench\nspreads over a mile radius, driving Pokémon\naway.
The foul fluid from its rear is so revolting that it\ncan make people feel queasy up to a mile and a\nquarter away.
It attacks by spraying a horribly smelly\nfluid from the tip of its tail. Attacks from\nabove confound it.
It attacks by spraying a repugnant fluid\nfrom its tail, but the stench dulls after\na few squirts.
Ancient people believed that the pattern on\nBronzor’s back contained a mysterious power.
They are found in ancient tombs. The patterns on\ntheir backs are said to be imbued with mysterious\npower.
In ages past, this Pokémon was revered as a\nbringer of rain. It was found buried in the ground.
It brought rains by opening portals to\nanother world. It was revered as a bringer\nof plentiful harvests.
In order to adjust the level of fluids in its body, it\nexudes water from its eyes. This makes it appear\nto be crying.
From its eyes, it can expel excess moisture from\nits body. This liquid is similar in composition to\nhuman sweat.
It carries a round, white rock in its belly pouch.\nIf it gets along well with someone, it will\nsometimes give that person the rock.
It carefully carries a round, white rock that it\nthinks is an egg. It’s bothered by how curly its\nhair looks.
Its constant mischief and misdeeds resulted\nin it being bound to an Odd Keystone by a\nmysterious spell.
It was formed by uniting 108 spirits. It has been\nbound to the Odd Keystone to keep it from\ndoing any mischief.
It skulks in caves, and when prey or an enemy\npasses by, it leaps out and chomps them.\nThe force of its attack sometimes chips its teeth.
It nests in horizontal holes warmed by geothermal\nheat. Foes who get too close can expect to be\npounced on and bitten.
In rare cases, it molts and sheds its scales.\nMedicine containing its scales as an ingredient\nwill make a weary body feel invigorated.
It loves sparkly things. It seeks treasures in\ncaves and hoards the loot in its nest.
It is said that when one runs at high speed,\nits wings create blades of wind that can fell\nnearby trees.
The protuberances on its head serve as\nsensors. It can even detect distant prey.
It needs to consume its own weight in food every\nday. As far as flavor is concerned, it’s indifferent.
When it is voraciously gulping down food,\nit forgets about the food it has hidden under\nits fur.
They communicate with one another using their\nauras. They are able to run all through the night.
It has the peculiar power of being able to see\nemotions, such as joy and rage, in the form\nof waves.
It’s said that no foe can remain invisible to\nLucario, since it can detect auras—even those\nof foes it could not otherwise see.
A well-trained one can use its aura to identify\nand take in the feelings of creatures over half a\nmile away.
It shuts its nostrils tight, then travels through\nsand as if walking. They form colonies of\naround 10.
It shrouds itself in sand to ward off germs.\nIt travels easily through the sands of the\ndesert.
It is surprisingly quick to anger. It holds its\nmouth agape as a display of its strength.
It brandishes its gaping mouth in a\ndisplay of fearsome strength. It raises\nvast quantities of sand while attacking.
Inflating its poison sacs, it fills the area with an\nodd sound and hits flinching opponents with a\npoison jab.
It rarely fights fairly, but that is strictly to ensure\nsurvival. It is popular as a mascot.
Swaying and dodging the attacks of its foes, it\nweaves its flexible body in close, then lunges\nout with its poisonous claws.
It has a poison sac at its throat. When it\ncroaks, the stored poison is churned for\ngreater potency.
The line running down its side can store sunlight.\nIt shines vividly at night.
It absorbs sunlight with the pink areas of its skin,\nwhich then shine. This appears to be a form of\ncamouflage.
With its shining light, it lures its prey close.\nHowever, the light also happens to attract\nferocious fish Pokémon—its natural predators.
Lumineon swimming in the darkness of the deep\nsea look like stars shining in the night sky.
During cold seasons, it migrates to the\nmountain’s lower reaches. It returns to the\nsnow-covered summit in the spring.
Seemingly curious about people, they\ngather around footsteps they find on\nsnowy mountains.
It lives a quiet life on mountains that\nare perpetually covered in snow.\nIt hides itself by whipping up blizzards.
They appear when the snow flowers\nbloom. When the petals fall, they\nretreat to places unknown again.
Evolution made it even more devious.\nIt communicates by clawing signs in boulders.
They travel in groups of four or five, leaving signs\nfor one another on trees and rocks. They bring\ndown their prey with coordinated attacks.
As it zooms through the sky, this Pokémon seems\nto be receiving signals of unknown origin while\ntransmitting signals of unknown purpose.
Exposure to a special magnetic field\nchanged Magneton’s molecular\nstructure, turning it into Magnezone.
This Pokémon’s sturdy carapace protects\nit from volcanic eruptions. It shoots round\nrocks from the holes in its hands.
A Rhyperior’s brain is smaller than a Rhydon’s,\nbut the Rhyperior is stronger because it spends\nmore energy on battling and less on brainpower.
When it gets excited, it thumps its chest.\nWith every thud, thunder roars and electric\nsparks shower all around.
This Pokémon presses the tips of its tails onto\nan opponent and instantly sends over 20,000\nvolts of high-voltage electricity through them.
When shooting 3,600 degree Fahrenheit\nfireballs from its arms, its body takes on a\nwhitish hue from the intense heat.
They dwell in volcanic craters. It’s said that\nonly a single pair of Magmortar will inhabit\nany given volcano.
Yanmega’s wingbeats are so powerful that\nthe Pokémon blows down huge trees nearby\nwhen it vigorously launches itself into flight.
Its jaw power is incredible. It is adept at biting\napart foes while flying by at high speed.
When you see Leafeon asleep in a patch of\nsunshine, you’ll know it is using photosynthesis\nto produce clean air.
The younger they are, the more they smell like\nfresh grass. With age, their fragrance takes on the\nodor of fallen leaves.
It can control its body temperature at will.\nThis enables it to freeze the moisture in the\natmosphere, creating flurries of diamond dust.
It lowers its body heat to freeze its fur. The hairs\nthen become like needles it can fire.
If it succeeds in catching even a faint breeze\nproperly, it can circle the globe without\nflapping once.
It flies soundlessly through the sky. It catches\nprey with its long tail, then lunges at the\nprey’s vulnerable spots with its fangs.
A frozen Mamoswine was dug from\nice dating back 10,000 years. This Pokémon\nhas been around a long, long, long time.
A frozen one was dug up from\nsoil dating back 10,000 years.\nIt woke up, to much amazement.
An additional program was installed to create a\nmore advanced Pokémon, but it was apparently\nflawed. Porygon-Z moves oddly as a result.
Its programming was modified to enable it to\noperate in other dimensions. This did not work as\nplanned.
When trying to protect someone, it extends its\nelbows as if they were swords and fights savagely.
Because it can sense what its foe is thinking,\nits attacks burst out first, fast, and fierce.
It controls three units called Mini-Noses using\nmagnetic force. With them, it can attack a foe\nfrom three directions.
Probopass radiates such a powerful magnetic\nfield that nearby electrical appliances are\nrendered useless while it’s around.
It is said to take lost spirits into its pliant body\nand take them to the afterlife.
It comes and goes between this world and the\nafterlife. People fear this Pokémon because it is\nsaid to suck in lost spirits and take them along.
When it finds humans or Pokémon it likes,\nit freezes them and takes them to its chilly\nden, where they become decorations.
It freezes prey by blowing its −58 degree\nFahrenheit breath. It is said to then secretly\ndisplay its prey.
Its electricity-like body can enter some kinds\nof machines and take control in order to make\nmischief.
Research continues on this Pokémon, which\ncould be the power source of a unique motor.
The leaf on Snivy’s tail generates energy when\nexposed to sunlight, making Snivy swifter and\nadding an edge to its moves.
It prefers to avoid groups. In its day-to-day life,\nit dexterously controls its vines to compensate\nfor its short arms.
It runs low to the ground, weaving through the\ngrass, then mercilessly pummels its target by\nwhipping them with its vines.
Servine’s one weakness is its inflated sense of\npride. It takes a while for Servine to be able to\ncooperate with other Pokémon.
It generates energy from sunlight, then\namplifies that energy dozens of times\nwithin its long body.
An intimidating gaze and majestic appearance\nhave caused this Pokémon to be known as the\nLord of the Forest.
It’s more nimble than it looks, and it uses its\nspeed to confound its enemies. It rapidly\nlaunches fireballs from both nostrils.
This Pokémon is a ravenous glutton. It uses its\nexcellent sense of smell to find food, then cooks\nit to a crisp before eating.
When Pignite enters battle, its body temperature\nrapidly soars until Pignite itself is engulfed by a\nscorching fireball.
When defending its friends, Pignite will stand\nup to any opponent, no matter how strong. But\nit’s powerless when faced with an empty stomach.
The flames blazing deep inside Emboar’s\nchest erupt vigorously from its chin, forming\na beard of fire.
The direr the situation, the more it seems to\nenjoy itself. The flames around its neck intensify,\ntoo, increasing Emboar’s power and speed.
It wields the scalchop on its stomach like a knife,\nblocking the moves of its enemies before slashing\nback at them in swift retaliation.
It’s said that Oshawott learned to maintain its\nscalchop with riverbed stones by mimicking\nhumans it saw using whetstones.
It’s said that people modeled swordplay after\nthe way Dewott’s movements flow like water\nwhile it’s wielding its two scalchops.
Dewott has a studious and stern personality.\nIt masters the use of its scalchops through\ndedicated, repeated training.
A master of a sword-drawing art called iaijutsu,\nSamurott settles its battles with a single swing of\neither large sword sheathed in its foreleg armor.
Samurott leads its group strictly. Those who do\nnot follow its rules receive a merciless thrashing.
Its heartbeat generates electricity. When Blitzle is\nsurprised and its heart rate goes up, the voltage\nof its electricity also rises.
This Pokémon prefers places with lots of lightning\nstrikes. It catches lightning with its mane and\nstores the electricity within its body.
This Pokémon is aggressive and has a volatile\ndisposition. When agitated, it will illuminate its\nmane in yellow and fire off bolts of electricity.
Once the herd hears thunder, it chases after the\nstorm clouds so that the Blitzle in the group can\nuse the lightning to charge up.
It can dig through the ground at a speed of\n30 mph. It could give a car running aboveground\na good race.
It makes its way swiftly through the soil by putting\nboth claws together and rotating at high speed.
Forming a drill with its steel claws and head,\nit can bore through a steel plate, no matter\nhow thick it is.
Its drill, which has evolved into steel, is strong\nenough to bore through iron plates. This\nPokémon is a great help in tunnel construction.
Always carrying squared logs, they help out\nwith construction. As they grow, they carry\nbigger logs.
It fights by swinging a piece of lumber around.\nIt is close to evolving when it can handle heavy\nlumber without difficulty.
They strengthen their bodies by carrying steel\nbeams. They show off their big muscles to their\nfriends.
This Pokémon is so muscular and strongly built\nthat even a group of wrestlers could not make it\nbudge an inch.
It is thought that Conkeldurr taught\nhumans how to make concrete more\nthan 2,000 years ago.
Rather than rely on their strength, they master\nmoves that make good use of centrifugal force\nto swing around concrete.
Sewaddle chews on leaves to make its clothing.\nIt’s trying to mimic the leafy garment Leavanny\nfirst dressed it in.
The bumps on their heads are sensory organs.\nWhen Sewaddle meet, they greet each other\nby rubbing these bumps together.
Swadloon lives quietly at the feet of trees.\nIt prefers eating fallen leaves that have grown\nsoft rather than fresh ones.
Swadloon wraps itself in leaves for protection.\nIt uses the two leaves atop its head to detect air\nmovements and feel out its surroundings.
This gentle Pokémon has strong protective\ninstincts. The leaves on its arms are sharp enough\nto slice a thick tree in half with one stroke.
It fashions clothing from woven leaves. Though\ngentle in disposition, it will show no mercy to\nfoes who target young Pokémon.
Pillows and beds stuffed with cotton exhaled by\nCottonee are soft and puffy, light and airy—\naltogether top quality.
When attacked, it escapes by shooting cotton\nfrom its body. The cotton serves as a decoy to\ndistract the attacker.
Like the wind, it can slip through any gap,\nno matter how small. It leaves balls of white\nfluff behind.
It rides on the wind and slips into people’s\nhomes. After it has turned a room into a cotton-\nfilled mess, it giggles to itself and takes off.
The leaves on its head grow right back even if\nthey fall out. These bitter leaves refresh those\nwho eat them.
If the leaves on its head are pruned with\nregularity, this Pokémon can be grown into\na fine plump shape.
The fragrance of the garland on its head has\na relaxing effect, but taking care of it is very\ndifficult.
No matter how much time and money is spent\nraising it, its flowers are the most beautiful when\nthey bloom in the wild.
Its temperament is vicious and aggressive.\nThis Pokémon is also full of vitality and can\nmultiply rapidly before anyone notices.
It’s so vicious that it’s called the Thug of the\nRiver. Yet Basculin is still targeted by predators,\nsuch as Dondozo and Bombirdier.
It submerges itself in sand and moves as if\nswimming. This wise behavior keeps its enemies\nfrom finding it and maintains its temperature.
They live hidden under hot desert sands in\norder to keep their body temperature from\ndropping.
Protected by thin membranes, their eyes can see\neven in the dead of night. They live in groups of\na few individuals.
Thanks to the special membrane covering its\neyes, it can see its surroundings clearly, even in\nthe middle of the night.
After clamping down with its powerful jaws, it\ntwists its body around to rip its prey in half.
Its unique faculty of sight can detect small prey\nmore than 30 miles away, even in the midst of\na sandstorm.
It stretches its saggy skin up to its neck to\nprotect itself. Among Scraggy, individuals with\nsaggier skin apparently garner more respect.
It will abruptly headbutt anyone that makes eye\ncontact with it. Its skull is extremely hard.
Groups of them beat up anything that enters\ntheir territory. Each can spit acidic liquid from\nits mouth.
This Pokémon may be rude, but it takes very\ngood care of its family, its friends, and its turf.
It changes into the forms of others to surprise\nthem. Apparently, it often transforms into a\nsilent child.
To protect themselves from danger, they hide\ntheir true identities by transforming into people\nand Pokémon.
Stories say those who tried to catch Zoroark\nwere trapped in an illusion and punished.
Each has the ability to fool a large group of\npeople simultaneously. They protect their lair\nwith illusory scenery.
When its tail has gotten dirty from self-cleaning\nor from cleaning its nest, Minccino spends a\nwhole day washing its tail in clean springwater.
These Pokémon like things neat and tidy. They\nare always sweeping and dusting their habitat,\nusing their tails as brooms.
Their white fur is coated in a special oil that\nmakes it easy for them to deflect attacks.
The oil that seeps from its body is really smooth.\nFor people troubled by bad skin, this oil is an\neffective treatment.
This Pokémon is normally very innocent. When it\nis staring at something invisible, it is unblinking\nand utterly silent.
Beware of touching the ribbon-shaped feelers\nthat control its psychic power. Gothita will begin\nbawling if you do.
This Pokémon will hypnotize children to put them\nto sleep before carrying them away. Be wary of\nnights when the starlight is bright.
Using its psychic power, it arranges pebbles to\nform the shapes of constellations. Some people\nbelieve this Pokémon came from outer space.
Gothitelle unleashes psychic energy and shows\nopponents dreams of the universe’s end. These\ndreams are apparently ethereal and beautiful.
It gazes at the stars to predict the future. It acts\nsomewhat detached because it has seen the end\nof all existence.
Because their bodies are enveloped in a special\nliquid, they can survive in any environment.
They drive away attackers by unleashing psychic\npower. They can use telepathy to talk with others.
Since they have two divided brains, at times\nthey suddenly try to take two different actions\nat once.
When their brains, now divided in two, are\nthinking the same thoughts, these Pokémon\nexhibit their maximum power.
Their arms are made of a special liquid. They\nuse psychic power to control these arms and\ncrush boulders.
When Reuniclus shake hands, a network\nforms between their brains, increasing their\npsychic power.
It’s not very good at flying yet. It watches the\ndances of its Swanna parents to learn how to\nmove its wings.
It strengthens its body by diving into the depths\nof ponds, swimming around while looking for\nbog moss to eat.
Centered around its leader, the flock dances in\nperfect sync to strengthen its unity.
It’s said that many artists have taken inspiration\nfrom the sight of a Swanna performing a beautiful\ndance in the light of dawn.
Deerling have different scents depending on the\nseason. In early spring, these Pokémon give off a\ndelicate, sweet, and calming scent.
Despite Deerling’s adorable appearance, farmers\nconsider it a nuisance since it loves plant shoots\nand will eat them all up.
It seems that a Sawsbuck with many flowers on its\nantlers will grow at a slightly slower pace because\nthe flowers absorb the Pokémon’s nutrients.
There are many Sawsbuck enthusiasts. The paler\nthe pink flowers that bloom on its antlers, the\nmore beautiful the Sawsbuck is considered to be.
There is a theory that the developer of the\nmodern-day Poké Ball really liked Foongus,\nbut this has not been confirmed.
This Pokémon prefers damp places. It spurts out\npoison spores to repel approaching enemies.
Be wary of the poisonous spores it releases.\nMushrooms resembling Amoonguss’s caps will\ngrow out of anywhere the spores touch.
Amoonguss mimics Poké Balls. It is not yet\nclear whether this mimicry is effective against\nother Pokémon.
It gently holds injured and weak Pokémon in its\nfins. Its special membrane heals their wounds.
They float upon the open sea. Many water\nPokémon gather in the area around Alomomola.
Joltik that live in cities have learned a technique\nfor sucking electricity from the outlets in houses.
Since it can’t generate its own electricity, it sticks\nonto large-bodied Pokémon and absorbs static\nelectricity.
They employ an electrically charged web\nto trap their prey. While it is immobilized\nby shock, they leisurely consume it.
When attacked, they create an electric\nbarrier by spitting out many electrically\ncharged threads.
While one alone doesn’t have much power,\na chain of many Tynamo can be as powerful\nas lightning.
These Pokémon move in schools. They have an\nelectricity-generating organ, so they discharge\nelectricity if in danger.
They coil around foes and shock them with\nelectricity-generating organs that seem simply\nto be circular patterns.
These Pokémon have a big appetite. When they\nspot their prey, they attack it and paralyze it with\nelectricity.
They crawl out of the ocean using their arms.\nThey will attack prey on shore and immediately\ndrag it into the ocean.
It latches on to prey with its sucker mouth,\nsinking in its fangs and shocking the prey with\npowerful electricity.
Its flame is usually out, but it starts shining\nwhen Litwick absorbs life-force from people\nor Pokémon.
While shining a light and pretending to be a\nguide, it leeches off the life-force of any who\nfollow it.
Lampent appears at the moment of death and\npromptly absorbs the spirit as it leaves the body.
The spirits it absorbs fuel its baleful fire. It hangs\naround hospitals waiting for people to pass on.
The spirits burned up in its ominous flame lose\ntheir way and wander this world forever.
It absorbs spirits, which it then burns. By waving\nthe flames on its arms, it puts its foes into a\nhypnotic trance.
This Pokémon lives in nests that are made in the\nground. People in ancient times used its tusks as\ncooking knives.
If you see peculiar teeth marks on boulders or\ntrees, it means an Axew is likely living nearby.
Because its tusks don’t grow back once they\nbreak, this Pokémon apparently won’t use them\nunless truly necessary.
Fraxure uses its thick tusks to neatly cut prey into\ntwo portions—one to eat now and one to save\nfor later.
This Pokémon nests in caves and abandoned\nmines. It is docile, but it will become incredibly\nangry if its tusks are touched, so beware.
It overwhelms enemies with its prized tusks,\nwhich are sharp enough to cut through a metal\ntransmission tower in one strike.
Many of this species can be found along the\nshorelines of cold regions. If a Cubchoo lacks\ndangling snot, there’s a chance it is sick.
When Cubchoo starts sneezing, watch out!\nIf it spatters you with its frosty snot, you’ll\nget frostbite.
It is a ferocious, carnivorous Pokémon.\nOnce it captures its prey, it will breathe cold\nair onto the prey to freeze and preserve it.
Feared as the Snow-White Demon in\nnorthern lands, Beartic uses its frosty\nclaws and fangs to attack prey.
Cryogonal appear during cold seasons. It is said\nthat people and Pokémon who die on snowy\nmountains are reborn into these Pokémon.
Cryogonal uses its chains of ice to constrict its\nopponents and then flash-freezes them where\nthey stand.
In fights, they dominate with onslaughts of\nflowing, continuous attacks. With their sharp\nclaws, they cut enemies.
They seclude themselves in the mountains and\ndevote themselves to training. The form of their\nkicks and chops differs from pack to pack.
When Mienshao lets out a bizarre wail, you’re in\ndanger. A flurry of kicks and chops too fast to\nsee is about to be unleashed!
Using the long fur on its arms like whips, it\nlaunches into combo attacks that, once started,\nno one can stop.
These Pokémon are thought to have been\ncreated by the science of an ancient and\nmysterious civilization.
Its movements are powered by a mysterious\nenergy. It has continued to move since ancient\ntimes, so its power may soon run out.
When the seal on its chest is removed, it rages\nindiscriminately. During such rampages, it can\nturn a whole town into a mountain of rubble.
Golurk were created by ancient people to\nprotect both people and Pokémon. They run\non a mysterious energy.
Pawniard will fearlessly challenge even powerful\nfoes. In a pinch, it will cling to opponents and\npierce them with the blades all over its body.
Any chips in its blades would prove fatal for it.\nAfter each battle, it diligently maintains its\nblades using its favorite sharpening stone.
This Pokémon commands a group of several\nPawniard. Groups that are defeated in territorial\ndisputes are absorbed by the winning side.
Bisharp mercilessly cuts its opponents to pieces\nwith the sharp blades covering its body. It will do\nanything to win.
They pick fights indiscriminately. They grow\nstronger and more powerful each time they\nfaint or are injured.
With its sharp claws, this Pokémon pierces its\nprey, and then it pecks at them. Although it also\nconsumes berries, it’s a carnivore at heart.
The more scars they have, the more\nrespect these brave soldiers of the\nsky get from their peers.
For the sake of its friends, this brave\nwarrior of the sky will not stop battling,\neven if injured.
They tend to guard their posteriors with suitable\nbones they have found. They pursue weak\nPokémon.
Its healthy appetite leads to visible growth spurts.\nIt often has to replace the bones it wears as its\nsize increases.
It’s always searching for food for Vullaby. When\nit finds a weak Pokémon, Mandibuzz swoops it\nright off to its nest.
Watching from the sky, they attack weakened\nprey on the ground. They have a habit of\ndecorating themselves with bones.
It can’t see, so its first approach to examining\nthings is to bite them. You will be covered in\nwounds until a Deino warms up to you.
It nests deep inside a cave. Food there is scarce,\nso Deino will sink its teeth into anything that\nmoves and attempt to eat it.
The two heads do not get along at all. If you\ndon’t give each head the same amount of\nattention, they’ll begin fighting out of jealousy.
The two heads have different likes and dislikes.\nBecause the heads fight with each other, Zweilous\ngets stronger without needing to rely on others.
Only the central head has a brain. It is very\nintelligent, but it thinks only of destruction.
It’s said that Hydreigon grew ferocious because\npeople in times long past loathed it, considering\nit to be evil incarnate and attacking it relentlessly.
This Pokémon was called the Larva That Stole\nthe Sun. The fire Larvesta spouts from its horns\ncan cut right through a sheet of iron.
In ancient times, Larvesta was worshiped as the\nemissary of the sun. However, it was also viewed\nas a burden since it often caused forest fires.
Its burning body causes it to be unpopular in hot\nparts of the world, but in cold ones, Volcarona is\nrevered as an embodiment of the sun.
This Pokémon scatters burning scales. Most of the\ndanger of these scales is not in their heat—it’s in\nthe way they rob the surrounding air of oxygen.
When Chespin tenses up just before landing a\nheadbutt, the spikes on its head sharpen to\npoints, piercing the enemy’s body on contact.
Eating lots of berries makes the bark shell that\ncovers Chespin’s head and body grow sturdier.
It’s protected by a sturdy shell. The shell is\nalso very heavy, which naturally strengthens\nQuilladin’s lower body.
It can send a trailer flying with a tackle. It’s numb\nto pain, so even violent collisions don’t faze it.
When its allies are in trouble, Chesnaught\ncreates a shield with its arms and uses its\nown body to block attacks.
Its gentle disposition would have it avoid\nconflict, but it gives opponents a thrashing with\nits thorned fists when the situation calls for it.
This Pokémon gets worked up easily. Its body\ncan also overheat, so it uses its ears to dissipate\nthe heat and calm down.
Twigs make for Fennekin’s snacks. When it\nnibbles on twigs, it finds the courage to face\nstrong foes.
It ignites the twig from its tail and waves the twig\naround to signal its allies. To indicate danger,\nit draws circles in the air with the twig’s flame.
Braixen’s branch ignites as it’s pulled from the\nPokémon’s tail. Braixen then uses the flame to\nspark powerful attacks.
It leaves burn marks in the ground with the flame\nat the tip of its wand. Long ago, people used the\nshapes of these burn marks for divination.
It controls flames telekinetically, trapping its\nfoes in a fiery vortex surpassing 5,400 degrees\nFahrenheit and burning them to a crisp.
Its happy-go-lucky look is an act intended to fool\nits enemies. It will suddenly drop the facade and\noverwhelm its foes with its blinding speed.
It utilizes its extraordinary jumping abilities to\nflummox its foes, throwing springy bubbles\nat them from above their heads.
It excels at devising battle strategies that make\nuse of the terrain, and it never misses its mark\nwhen throwing bubble-covered pebbles.
The tips of its fingers and toes stick firmly to\nvertical surfaces. Frogadier can scale skyscrapers\nwith ease.
The movement of air against the long tongue\nGreninja keeps wrapped around its neck allows\nit to sense enemies it can’t see.
It makes shuriken out of mucus excreted from its\nthighs. These shuriken can cut cleanly through\nsteel cables.
This Pokémon is normally calm, but once it\nenters battle, its hormonal balance changes\nand it becomes aggressive.
Fletchling can be found in both rural and urban\nareas. They once had a huge territorial dispute\nwith Squawkabilly. Fights broke out all over town.
Fletchinder scatters embers in tall grass\nwhere bug Pokémon might be hiding and\nthen catches them as they come leaping out.
Its territory has a radius of just over a mile.\nIf any bird Pokémon should enter, it will show\nthem no mercy.
It has top-notch flying capabilities. It flies\naround easily, even while carrying prey\nthat weighs more than 220 lbs.
When it gets excited, it vents sparks from the\ngaps between its feathers. These unburnable\nfeathers are used as a fireproof material.
Any poison this Pokémon takes in is converted\ninto a black powder and secreted. That’s why\nScatterbug can eat poisonous leaves and roots.
This Pokémon scatters poisonous powder\nto repel enemies. It will eat different plants\ndepending on where it lives.
If Rufflet attacks this Pokémon by pecking at it,\nit will retaliate with its sharp fur and poisonous\nblack powder.
Spewpa doesn’t live in a fixed location. It roams\nwhere it pleases across the fields and mountains,\nbuilding up the energy it needs to evolve.
The patterns on this Pokémon depend on the\nclimate and topography of the land it was born\nin. This form is from frigid lands.
This Pokémon was born in frigid lands.\nIt scatters colorful, toxic scales from its\nwings during battle.
When Litleo are young, female Pyroar will teach\nthem how to hunt. Once the Litleo mature, they\nwill leave the pride and set out on their own.
The more a Litleo trains its body and spirit by\nbattling mighty enemies, the hotter its mane\nwill grow.
The females of a pride work together to bring\ndown prey. It’s thanks to them that their pride\ndoesn’t starve.
The mane of a male Pyroar heats up to over\n3,600 degrees Fahrenheit during battle. Merely\napproaching it will cause severe burns.
This Pokémon can draw forth the power hidden\nwithin blooming wild flowers. It is particularly\nfond of red flowers.
This Flabébé rides a red flower. Immediately\nafter birth, this Pokémon begins flying around in\nsearch of a flower it likes.
This Pokémon draws forth what power is left in\nwithered flowers to make them healthy again.\nIt holds a red flower.
This Pokémon uses red wavelengths of light to\npour its own energy into flowers and draw forth\ntheir latent potential.
This Pokémon creates an impressive flower\ngarden in its territory. It draws forth the power\nof the red flowers around its neck.
They say that flower gardens created by Florges\nare constantly showered with a power that can\nheal both body and spirit.
Until recently, people living in the mountains\nwould ride on the backs of these Pokémon to\ntraverse the mountain paths.
As long as it has sunlight and water, Skiddo can\nmake energy with the leaves on its body, allowing\nit to live on rocky mountains barren of food.
It can sense the feelings of others by touching\nthem with its horns. This species has assisted\npeople with their work since 5,000 years ago.
These Pokémon live in herds in mountainous\nplaces. The victor in their contests of clashing\nhorns will become the leader of the herd.
It keeps its ears covered to prevent the intense\npsychic power in its body from escaping, but it\nfalls unconscious if this power builds too much.
Behind an Espurr’s expressionless face is a frantic\nstruggle to contain psychic power.
Though it has enough psychic power to blast\naway any opponent, Meowstic prefers to support\nits allies rather than attack.
If Meowstic continuously emits its powerful\npsychic energy, it will damage its own body.
It protects itself from tough foes by flashing its\nluminescent spots to discourage them.
Being upside-down improves its blood flow and\nclears its mind, causing the power of its psychic\nmoves to increase dramatically.
Its hypnotic powers are dangerously strong.\nAnyone who falls under Malamar’s control\nloses their memories surrounding the event.
It flashes the luminescent spots on its body\nto hypnotize its opponents, gaining total\ncontrol over them.
Skrelp evades its enemies by hiding amid\ndrifting seaweed. It eats rotten seaweed to\ncreate its poison.
This Pokémon is a poor swimmer. If it’s caught in\na fierce storm, it will sometimes get washed far\naway and become unable to return to its home.
Using a liquid poison, Dragalge indiscriminately\nattacks anything that wanders into its territory.\nThis poison can corrode the undersides of boats.
Since Finizen is the better swimmer, Dragalge\nwill approach it under the cover of seaweed,\nthen immobilize it with a poisonous attack.
This Pokémon launches water by detonating gas\ninside its right claw. It snipes flying Pokémon.
Clauncher’s claws will regrow if they fall off. The\nmeat inside the claws is edible, but it has a\ndistinct flavor that doesn’t appeal to all tastes.
Clawitzer can move through the water at\na speed of 60 knots by using gas inside its\nbody to expel water from the back of its claw.
The cannonballs of seawater that Clawitzer\nlaunches from its claw are powerful\nenough to punch through tanker hulls.
This Pokémon uses its ribbonlike feelers to send\na soothing aura into its opponents, erasing\ntheir hostility.
Sylveon cuts an elegant figure as it dances lightly\naround, feelers fluttering, but its piercing moves\naim straight for its opponents’ weak spots.
Its elegant finishing moves—performed by nimbly\nleaping around using its wings—are polished in\nthe forest where it was born and raised.
Hawlucha live quietly without flocking together.\nThey fight constantly with their natural enemies:\nnoisy groups of Primeape.
It’s small and its electricity-generating organ is\nnot fully developed, so it uses its tail to absorb\nelectricity from people’s homes and charge itself.
Dedenne emit electrical waves from the whiskers\non their cheeks to communicate with each other.\nWhen low on electricity, they curl up and sleep.
It has slept underground for hundreds of millions\nof years since its birth. It’s occasionally found\nduring the excavation of caves.
Born from the high temperatures and pressures\ndeep underground, it defends itself by firing\nbeams from the jewel part of its body.
Most of a Goomy’s body is water. A membrane\ncovers the whole Pokémon to prevent it from\nshriveling up in dry weather.
Goomy’s horns are excellent sensory organs that\ncover all five of Goomy’s senses. Goomy picks\nup on danger from the movement of the air.
The swirly protrusion on its back is filled with all\nits vital organs, such as its brain and heart.
When Sliggoo senses danger, the mucus coating\nits entire body becomes more concentrated—\nit’ll dissolve anything.
It loves the rain. This mellow Pokémon can be\nseen walking around on the plains and in the\nmountains on rainy days.
This Pokémon is uncontrollable when enraged.\nIt rampages on and on, lashing its tail with\nenough power to send a dump truck flying.
Once it absorbs a key’s metal ions, it discards the\nkey without a second thought. However, it will\nhang on to keys it favors for decades.
In the past, noble families entrusted their vault\nkeys to a Klefki. They passed the Klefki down\nthrough the generations, taking good care of it.
Legend tells that its green leaves can cure any\nillness. When plucked, however, the leaves will\ninstantly wither away.
This Pokémon came to be when the spirit of a\ndeceased child possessed a tree stump. It now\nwanders the forest searching for friends.
Using its roots, Trevenant connects itself\nto trees and monitors every corner of its forest.\nIt uses curses to drive intruders away.
Trevenant is very kind to Pokémon living in the\nforest. It doesn’t even care if these Pokémon\ntake up residence in the greenery on its head.
They live in mountainous regions of frigid cold.\nOn rare occasions, they ride on the back of an\nAvalugg to cross seas and move to new habitats.
Bergmite protects itself by coating its body in ice\nformed by frigid air of −148 degrees Fahrenheit.\nIt fights with Frigibax whenever they meet.
As Avalugg walks along with Bergmite\non its back, it comes across pods of\nCetitan. It lets them pass to avoid conflict.
This Pokémon uses its massive icy body to flatten\nanything that gets in its way. When it’s floating\nout on the ocean, it looks exactly like drift ice.
This Pokémon emits ultrasonic waves from its\nlarge ears to search for fruit to eat. It mistakes\nApplin for its food.
Noibat can change the frequency of its sound\nwaves at will, and it generates ultrasonic waves of\nup to 200,000 hertz.
Ultrasonic waves emitted by a Noivern\ncan pulverize a large boulder. This\nPokémon has a cruel disposition.
In the dark, even Hydreigon are terrified\nof this Pokémon. But in the light, Noivern\nis the one that avoids battle.
Silently it glides, streaking toward its targets to\nget close to them. Before they even notice it,\nit begins to pelt them with vicious kicks.
It feels relaxed in tight, dark places and has been\nknown to nestle into its Trainer’s bag or the front\nof their jacket.
This narcissistic Pokémon is a clean freak.\nIf you don’t groom it diligently, it may stop\nlistening to you.
It throws sharp feathers called blade quills at\nenemies or prey. It seldom misses.
It cunningly conceals arrow quills in its wings. It\nlaunches these quills with such precision that they\ncan pierce a pebble at over a hundred yards.
It nocks its arrow quills and looses them at\nopponents. When it needs to hit, it pulls the\nvines on its hood to narrow its view and focus.
If you try too hard to get close to it, it won’t\nopen up to you. Even if you do grow close,\ngiving it too much affection is still a no-no.
While grooming itself, it builds up fur inside its\nstomach. It sets the fur alight and spews fiery\nattacks, which change based on how it coughs.
At its throat, it bears a bell of fire. The bell rings\nbrightly whenever fire spews out.
Torracat will let its Trainer coddle it once they’ve\ngrown close, but it’s a powerful, sharp-clawed\nPokémon, so its Trainer gets covered in scratches.
When its fighting spirit is set alight, the flames\naround its waist become especially intense.
After hurling ferocious punches and flinging\nfurious kicks, it finishes opponents off by spewing\nfire from around its navel.
This Pokémon can control balloons made of\nwater. It practices diligently so it can learn to\nmake big balloons.
The balloons it inflates with its nose grow larger\nand larger as it practices day by day.
A skillful dancer, it creates a sequence of water\nballoons as it dances, then briskly bombards its\nenemies.
It cares deeply for its companions. When its\nTrainer is feeling down, it performs a cheery\ndance to try to help.
To Primarina, every battle is a stage. It takes\ndown its prey with beautiful singing and dancing.
Also known as a songstress, it is a sight to\nbehold on moonlit nights when it sings in\nfront of the colony it leads.
Using its beak to strike 16 times per second,\nit opens holes in even the hardest of trees.
Pikipek has strong muscles in its neck, so it won’t\nhurt itself even if it violently shakes its head.
It flies around using a hundred different cries in\nvarious ways to declare its territory to others.
When it encounters foes, it launches the many\nseeds stored in its beak in a radial burst.
The compressed gas in Toucannon’s beak\nlaunches seeds with such force that they can\nshatter large boulders.
Pairs of Toucannon are considered symbols of\ncompanionship, as these Pokémon will raise the\ntemperature of their beaks to warm each other.
Its stomach fills most of its torso. It wanders the\nsame path every day, searching for fresh food.
It spends its waking hours searching endlessly for\nfood. When Yungoos is hungry, its ferocity gains\na certain edge.
Once it finds signs of prey, it will patiently stake\nout the location, waiting until the sun goes down.
Gumshoos specializes in relentlessly tracking\ndown prey. The simple-minded Skwovet doesn’t\nseem to provide Gumshoos enough challenge.
Grubbin normally live underground, but if they\nget unearthed by Hoothoot, they may be found\ngathered around electric Pokémon.
It spits sticky threads and winds them around\nbranches, then swings nimbly from tree to tree\nin a pendulum-like motion.
Protected by a sturdy shell, Charjabug eats large\nquantities of fresh and decomposing leaf litter in\norder to evolve.
As it digests fallen leaves, it generates and stores\nelectricity, which it can discharge from the tips of\nits jaws.
Displaying exceptional mobility, it weaves\nbetween trees and shoots down bird Pokémon\nwith its electromagnetic beams.
When carrying a Charjabug, Vikavolt can receive\nelectricity from it and then rapidly fire powerful\nelectromagnetic beams from its large jaws.
This Pokémon punches trees and eats the\nberries that drop down, training itself\nand getting food at the same time.
If it loses its pincers, they’ll quickly regrow.\nThe pincers are popular ingredients in paella\nsince their shells produce a tasty soup stock.
The detached pincers of these Pokémon are\ndelicious. Some Trainers bring Lechonk into\nthe mountains just to search for them.
Though its punches are powerful, this Pokémon’s\nmovements are sluggish. It blows icy bubbles\nfrom its mouth to immobilize its opponents.
This Pokémon is incredibly popular, possibly\nbecause its passionate dancing is a great match\nwith the temperament of Paldean people.
This form of Oricorio has sipped red nectar.\nIt whips up blazing flames as it moves to the\nsteps of its passionate dance.
When it senses the auras of people or Pokémon\nwho are having fun, it will draw close and give\nthem a painful poke with its long proboscis.
Cutiefly sucks up pollen and nectar with its long\nproboscis. It stores any pollen it doesn’t finish\neating in its fur.
Ribombee can sense when people or Pokémon\nare feeling down, and it will cheer them up with\nhandmade pollen puffs.
Pollen puffs created by skilled Ribombee can\nrelieve fatigue, making the puffs a popular\ncommodity.
This Pokémon is very friendly when it’s young. Its\ndisposition becomes vicious once it matures, but\nit never forgets the kindness of its master.
This Pokémon travels in a pack with others until\nit grows up. When its mood turns sour, it starts\nstriking the ground with the rocks on its neck.
Lycanroc attacks its prey with its sharp claws and\nfangs. It loyally obeys the instructions of a Trainer\nit trusts.
It has a calm and collected demeanor. It swiftly\ncloses in on its prey, then slices them with the\nrocks in its mane.
This Pokémon wanders the seaside looking for\nfood. It often gets electric shocks from broken\nPincurchin spines that it tries to eat.
It has excellent regenerative capabilities. Legs\nthat a Mareanie has lost have a very bitter,\nastringent flavor—they’re not suitable as food.
This Pokémon lives within a dome made by its\nown legs. Toxapex monitors its surroundings by\nsensing the flow of the tide through its spikes.
Toxapex gets into fierce battles with Bruxish\nover areas where warm ocean currents\nflow, but the odds are always against it.
This Pokémon covers itself in mud that it has\nregurgitated. The mud won’t dry out even if it’s\nexposed to the sun for a long time.
Though a slow walker, Mudbray is plenty strong.\nIts pace doesn’t change even when it’s loaded\nwith 50 times its own body weight.
This Pokémon has been treasured not just for\nits physical labor but also because it produces\nhigh-quality mud used for making pottery.
Its legs are fortified with mud and harder than\nstone, and they can reduce a large truck to scrap\nwith one kick.
Dewpider uses sticky threads to create the water\nbubble that covers its head, so the bubble very\nrarely bursts.
It supports the water bubble that envelops its\nhead with three of its legs. Sometimes it secretly\nswaps which legs are holding up the bubble.
A caring Pokémon, Araquanid carries Dewpider\naround inside its water bubble to protect them as\nit walks. It protects its food in its bubble too.
It launches sticky water bubbles. Foes who lose\nconsciousness while trapped inside these bubbles\nwill get torn apart by Araquanid’s gnashing jaws.
Fomantis hates having its naps interrupted. It fires\noff beams using energy it gathers by bathing in\nthe sun.
Many Trainers give their Fomantis their own\nflowerpots so they can sunbathe in peace\nand quiet.
By masquerading as a bug Pokémon, it lowers the\nguard of actual bug Pokémon lured in by a scent\nof sweet flowers. Its sickles bring them down.
A lot of time and effort is required to maintain\nthe vivid colors of its petals. This Pokémon puts\nits Trainer’s attentiveness to the test.
It taunts its prey and lures them into narrow,\nrocky areas where it then sprays them with toxic\ngas to make them dizzy and take them down.
Only female Salandit can produce gas laden\nwith pheromones. Males entranced by this gas\nwill do whatever the females tell them.
Salazzle makes its opponents light-headed with\npoisonous gas, then captivates them with alluring\nmovements to turn them into loyal servants.
When two Salazzle meet, they will use their\npheromone gas to fight over the males in each\nother’s group.
Its sweat is sweet, like syrup made from boiled-\ndown fruit. Because of this, Bounsweet was highly\nvalued in the past, when sweeteners were scarce.
A Greedent drawn in by the sweet scent of these\nPokémon will tuck the Bounsweet in among the\nberries in its tail and carry them all away.
Steenee spreads a sweet scent that makes others\nfeel invigorated. This same scent is popular for\nantiperspirants.
Steenee bounces energetically through forests.\nIf the rind that peels off its body is pulverized,\nit can be used to treat stomach pains.
This Pokémon is proud and aggressive. However,\nit is said that a Tsareena will instantly become\ncalm if someone touches the crown on its calyx.
This Pokémon launches fierce yet elegant kicks\nwith its long, slender legs. It views Quaquaval as\nits rival.
It uses its vine to pick flowers. The flowers that\nComfey attaches to itself develop healing\nproperties.
It prefers areas with lots of flowers. A Comfey\nadorned with flowers is a happy Comfey, and the\nflowers gain healing effects.
People used to mistake Oranguru for a human\nwhen they saw it issue command after\ncommand to the other Pokémon of the forest.
This Pokémon lives quietly in the depths of the\nforest. The purple, cape-like fur gets longer\nand longer as Oranguru ages.
This Pokémon battles by throwing hard berries.\nIt won’t obey a Trainer who throws Poké Balls\nwithout skill.
The boss chooses 10 members of the group to\ngo out hunting. The hunting party will evenly split\nthe food they find with the rest of the group.
If it loses its shovel, it will stick something else—\nlike a branch—in its head to make do until it finds\nanother shovel.
It flings sand into the eyes of its prey and tries to\nclose in on them while they’re blinded, but since\nSandygast is so slow, the prey tends to escape.
The terrifying Palossand drags smaller Pokémon\ninto its sandy body. Once its victims are trapped,\nit drains them of their vitality whenever it pleases.
From the hollows in its arms, it fires the\nbones of its victims, which are all dried up\nafter being drained of their vitality.
This Pokémon is born in the ozone layer. It falls\nto the ground once the outer shell enclosing its\ncore grows heavy.
It will react when touched or called to, but it’s\nunknown whether such responses indicate\nconsciousness.
Komala spends its entire life sleeping. It feeds on\nleaves that contain a potent poison only Komala\ncan break down.
A potent anesthetic can be made by diluting\nKomala’s drool. This anesthetic was used for\nsurgeries in the past.
This Pokémon lives in dark places untouched by\nsunlight. When it appears before humans, it hides\nitself under a cloth that resembles a Pikachu.
Mimikyu was only recently identified as a\nPokémon. Previously, people thought it was\njust a ghost wearing a cloth.
It grinds its teeth with great force to stimulate\nits brain. It fires the psychic energy created by\nthis process from the protuberance on its head.
When sunlight reflects on the ripples created by\na Bruxish grinding its teeth, the water all around\nsparkles brilliantly.
The scale atop its head is useful for both offense\nand defense. It bravely stands and faces its foes\nrather than turning tail, even if its foes are strong.
They communicate with their allies using the\nsounds their scales make when struck. A group\nof these Pokémon causes quite a racket.
It gets into fistfights so intense that the scales\non its arms peel off. Bare arms are a sign of\nvaliance.
It fires itself up by striking its scales with force as\nit dances. Its roar is a battle cry.
It lets its arm hang, and then—quick as a flash—\nswings upward to land its specialty punch and\nsend the opponent flying high into the sky.
It bashes its scales to test its opponents’ mettle.\nThe sound of struck Kommo-o scales frightens\nweaker foes and sends them running.
The stick Grookey holds has grown harder and\nmore flexible after soaking in the energy that\nemanates from inside Grookey’s body.
As Grookey strikes everything in sight with its\nstick, it has more and more fun, and its rhythm\nbecomes livelier.
It skillfully uses its two sticks not only for\ndrumming out rapid beats but also for\npummeling opponents during battle.
It becomes intensely focused while it drums out\nvigorous beats—so much so that sometimes it\nwon’t listen to its Trainer’s commands.
Though it has a calm disposition, it won’t tolerate\nthose who drum up discord. It strictly disciplines\noffenders until they learn their lesson.
When one Rillaboom challenges another who\nleads a troop, a drumming battle commences.\nThe victor becomes the troop’s new boss.
Once its body has heated up, Scorbunny can use\nthe full extent of its power. That’s why it does\nwarm-up exercises.
Fire energy gathers in the pads of its feet,\nraising their temperature. Once hot, Scorbunny’s\nfootpads can deal heavy damage to opponents.
Thanks to its soft and fluffy fur, Raboot can easily\nheat up its fire energy and produce flames with\nmore power.
While it prides itself on its varied kicking moves,\nit can also deliver powerful headbutts once its\nflames have heated up its forehead.
Although Cinderace loses its cool easily, it will\nbattle flawlessly for a Trainer it trusts.
Using a ball that it made out of flames,\nCinderace blinds its opponents and\nkeeps them at bay.
It gets berries to eat by shooting them down\nwith bullets of water it spurts from its mouth.\nIts aim is perfect.
It’s a very cautious Pokémon. When it has\nno choice but to battle, it hides itself before\nattacking.
It extends its long, slimy tongue at blinding\nspeeds and finishes off its prey with great skill.
Highly intelligent but also very lazy, it defends its\nhome by laying traps.
It uses special lenses in its eyes to sense things\nabout its opponents—like their body heat—then\nattacks once it identifies a weak spot.
It may present itself as being well-mannered,\nbut deep down, it still has a lazy side. It will\nslack off when its Trainer isn’t looking.
It stores berries in its cheeks. When there are no\nberries to be found, Skwovet will stuff pebbles\ninto its cheeks to stave off its cravings.
No matter how much it stuffs its belly with food,\nit is always anxious about getting hungry again.\nSo, it stashes berries in its cheeks and tail.
If it spots a berry tree, it will immediately go to\ngather berries without a sideways glance—even if\nit’s in the middle of a battle.
This Pokémon makes off with heaps of fallen\nberries by wrapping them in its tail, which is\nroughly twice the length of its body.
This Pokémon is brave and reckless. The white\nmarkings around a Rookidee’s eyes intimidate\nfainthearted Pokémon.
The females are fussier than the males. If another\ncreature dirties a female Rookidee’s wings, it’ll\npeck the offender relentlessly in a burning rage.
It’s said that the reason behind Corvisquire’s\nhigh level of intelligence is the large size of its\nbrain relative to those of other bird Pokémon.
This intelligent Pokémon will quickly learn\nhow to use any tool it can hold in its beak\nor its talons.
Corviknight can’t serve as a taxi service in Paldea\nbecause the Pokémon’s natural predators will\nattack it while it flies, endangering the customer.
Although its wings have partly turned to\nsteel and become heavy as a result, this\nPokémon flies through the skies with ease.
Its large front tooth is still growing in. When the\ntooth itches, this Pokémon will bite another\nChewtle’s horn, and the two Pokémon will tussle.
A popular game among children is to lift up sticks\nthat Chewtle have bitten onto to see whose\nChewtle can hang on the longest.
Its massive, jagged teeth can crush a\nboulder in a single bite. This Pokémon\nhas an extremely vicious disposition.
Drednaw lurks along the shoreline. When\nprey come to drink water, Drednaw stretches\nits neck out and chomps down on them.
On sunny days, Rolycoly will come out onto\ngrassy plains and roll around. Then it will eat\nthe grass that gets tangled in its wheel-like leg.
Chunks of the surface of this Pokémon’s body\nthat have grown old and flaked off have long\nbeen used for fuel as an alternative to coal.
The temperature inside its body increases when\nit experiences strong emotions. It rolls around\nfrantically while spewing flames.
Due to the coal tar created inside it, the heap\nof coal on Carkol’s back never falls apart, even\nwhen the Pokémon rolls around at high speeds.
To intimidate its opponents, Coalossal will\nvigorously shake its body, scattering coal from\nits smoldering back.
It’s gentle usually but fearsome when angered.\nWith a body that burns at over 2,700 degrees\nFahrenheit, it crushes foes and turns them to ash.
It grows by eating the flesh of an apple.\nApplin uses its own body fluid to strengthen\nthe apple’s skin and prevent it from rotting.
Applin lives inside an apple. When an Applin is\nseparated from its apple, its body loses moisture\nand the Pokémon grows weak.
It flutters around while seeking an opening in\nthe opponent’s guard, then attacks by spitting\nacidic liquid strong enough to melt metal.
It uses its own body fluid to repair its apple.\nStrong Flapple that have won many battles have\napples that are clay colored all over.
It feeds mainly on sweet apples. It will also eat\nsmall bug Pokémon that are attracted by its\nsweet nectar.
When some Lechonk come along to lick the\nsweet nectar on Appletun’s back, Appletun will\nspew sticky nectar at them to drive them away.
Silicobra’s neck pouch, which can inflate and\ndeflate like a balloon, gets more elastic each\ntime Silicobra sheds its skin.
Silicobra’s large nostrils are specialized for\nspraying sand, so this Pokémon is not very good\nat telling apart different smells.
It will expand its body as much as it can\nand then contract itself, blasting out sand\nwith enough force to wash away a dump truck.
The sand it spews contains sharp, pointy gravel,\nwhich is actually just sand that Sandaconda’s\nsaliva has hardened into irregular shapes.
Cramorant instinctively swallow everything whole.\nThey’re at their most formidable when they’re\nstruggling to swallow overly large prey.
It’s an incredibly poor learner because it uses the\nbare minimum amount of energy for its brain.\nIt focuses on battling instead.
Arrokuda can swim quickly only in a straight line.\nThe ones that become sluggish from overeating\nare the first to be targeted by flocks of Wattrel.
It takes down prey by charging into them with\nits hard, pointed jaw. But Arrokuda’s eyesight is\npoor, so this tactic has a low success rate.
It spins its tail fins to leap from the water, then\nviciously bites down on Wingull flying close to\nthe water’s surface.
It swims at speeds of over 100 knots and\nbattles fiercely with pods of Finizen over prey.
It has no problem drinking dirty water.\nAn organ inside Toxel’s body filters such water\ninto a poisonous liquid that is harmless to Toxel.
This selfish, attention-seeking Pokémon stores\npoison and electricity in two different sacs inside\nits body.
As it scatters toxic sweat and emits electricity,\na melody that sounds like it came from a guitar\nreverberates through the surrounding area.
The jolts of electricity it launches by violently\nstrumming the protrusions on its chest easily\nexceed 15,000 volts.
The soul of someone who died alone possessed\nsome leftover tea. This Pokémon appears in\nhotels and houses.
Sinistea gets into your body when you drink it,\nand then it steals your vitality from within. It also\ntastes awful.
The tea that composes Polteageist’s body has a\ndistinct and enjoyable flavor. Drinking too much,\nhowever, can be fatal.
These Pokémon multiply by creeping into teapots\nand pouring themselves into leftover tea.
Because the emotions of others constantly flow\ninto its head, this Pokémon prefers environments\nwhere no other creatures live.
It senses the feelings of other living creatures.\nBe careful not to expose it to strong emotions\nfor too long, or it will end up exhausted.
To this Pokémon, strong emotions apparently feel\nlike incredibly loud noises—even if the emotions\nare happy ones.
The moment this Pokémon finds someone who’s\nemitting strong emotions, it will pummel them\nsenseless with its braids to silence them.
Hatterene knocks out those that intrude in its\nhome forest by blasting them with a beam, then\nslashing with claws enhanced by psychic power.
Beware of forests that show no signs of living\ncreatures within. You may have wandered into\nHatterene’s territory.
The reason this Pokémon causes trouble for those\nit feels close to is because Impidimp itself gets\nirritable if it can’t absorb negative emotions.
They live in groups, pestering and playing pranks\non each other to polish their troublemaking skills.
Morgrem prefers dirty tactics, like ambushing,\nbecause it doesn’t have confidence in its brawn.
This Pokémon absorbs negative emotions and\nturns them into energy. It’s popular with people\nwho tend to think gloomy thoughts.
This Pokémon has complete control over its\nhair. Grimmsnarl normally keeps its hair\nwrapped around its body to support its muscles.
It lives deep within the forest. Even after\nevolving into this splendid form, it hasn’t\ngiven up on its petty misdeeds and pranks.
The more sweet aromas it absorbs, the more its\nbody swells. Milcery will deflate when its energy\nlevel drops.
When attacked, it tackles its foe and covers\nthem in cream. With its foe either blinded or\nastonished by deliciousness, Milcery flees.
Desserts that Alcremie have decorated with\ntheir cream have a rich, sweet flavor and bring\nhappiness to all who eat them.
Alcremie that have been cherished produce\nexquisite cream, so Trainers always raise them\nlovingly.
The brass, which is the one that stands at the\nfront and issues orders, is the strongest and\nsmartest of the six.
The leader, known as the brass, uses its\nextendible horn to issue orders to the\nothers when it’s time to change formation.
This Pokémon generates electricity when it\ndigests food. It uses its five hard teeth to scrape\nseaweed off surfaces and eat it.
This Pokémon is so timid that even brushing\nagainst seaweed will make it discharge electricity\nin surprise. Its lips do not conduct electricity.
It eats snow that has accumulated on the ground.\nIt prefers soft, freshly fallen snow, so it will eat its\nway up a mountain, aiming for the peak.
Within its internal organs, Snom amplifies the\nfrigid air it gets from eating snow and then uses\nthis amplified air to create icicle-like spikes.
Frosmoth senses air currents with its antennae.\nIt sends its scales drifting on frigid air, making\nthem fall like snow.
It causes blizzards as it flies around with its huge,\nchill-emanating wings. Clean meltwater is its\nfavorite thing to drink.
The elemental composition of the rocks that\nform its body were found to match the bedrock\nof a land far away from this Pokémon’s habitat.
This Pokémon spends its life gazing at the setting\nsun. It strides leisurely across grassy plains on\nlegs of rock that weigh over 400 pounds each.
On hot days, these Pokémon press their ice cube\nheads together and pass the time cooling each\nother down.
If you lick the ice covering its face, you’ll find it\nhas a faintly salty taste. This species rode here on\nocean currents from a cold, faraway land.
This Pokémon picks up on the positive emotions\nof other creatures via its horns and uses those\nemotions to fuel itself.
This Pokémon never leaves its Trainer’s side.\nIt predicts their actions with its psychic power\nand takes care of their day-to-day needs.
Morpeko eats seeds constantly to keep its hunger\nat bay. If it’s hungry for too long, it grows wild\nand brutish.
It has a small stomach. If it isn’t constantly eating\nthe seeds it keeps in its pockets, it will get hungry\nimmediately.
Using the pointy tip of its trunk, it carves off\nchunks of hard rocks to eat. It is very docile\nand helps people with physical labor.
Cufant can lift loads weighing five tons. In the\nmornings, it heads into caves with its herd, in\nsearch of the ore on which these Pokémon feed.
This Pokémon was brought to Paldea long\nago by people from a faraway land. It’s so\nstrong that it can easily pull an airplane.
Copperajah are prideful, cantankerous Pokémon.\nSpecimens with vibrant green skin command the\nrespect of others of their kind.
Duraludon’s body is comprised of a special metal\nthat’s lightweight and scratch resistant. It’s also\nsmooth, as though it was given a mirror finish.
Its metal body is durable but prone to\nretaining heat. It vents this heat from the\nslits in its tail.
In the evening, groups of Dreepy will fly at high\nspeeds over the ocean and poke at Pokémon in\nthe water for fun.
It has a habit of biting at Clauncher even though\nit doesn’t feed on them. This is said to be\nvestigial behavior from when Dreepy was alive.
This Pokémon flies around at over 120 miles per\nhour. If a Drakloak is defeated in a battle, its\nDreepy will wander off without a second thought.
This Pokémon stores up energy in its lungs, then\nshoots it out. It takes care of Dreepy and battles\nalongside them until they’re all grown up.
Dragapult can make its whole body transparent\nby clearing its mind and focusing. Even the\nDreepy in Dragapult’s horns become invisible.
The fastest Dragapult of the group is always\nsurrounded by Dreepy that want to fly at\nsonic speed.
Parts of its body turned to stone when\nit evolved thanks to an extremely rare\nore found in volcanic areas.
This Pokémon is a rough, crude, and\nviolent sort. It swings around its large,\nheavy stone axes to finish off its prey.
This Pokémon is cloaked in the souls of its\ncomrades who perished during a punishing\njourney to the river of their birth.
It can jump with incredible power. Parts of its\nbody are tinged red by the rage of its fallen\nfriends.
Overqwil’s poisonous spikes will reflexively react\neven while Overqwil sleeps, stabbing any moving\nthing that approaches.
It’s ferocious and has a short temper. The ends of\nits spikes are barbed, and they can’t be easily\nremoved once they’ve punctured something.
Its fluffy fur is similar in composition to plants.\nThis Pokémon frequently washes its face to keep\nit from drying out.
The sweet scent its body gives off mesmerizes\nthose around it. The scent grows stronger when\nthis Pokémon is in the sun.
Floragato deftly wields the vine hidden beneath\nits long fur, slamming the hard flower bud against\nits opponents.
The hardness of Floragato’s fur depends on the\nPokémon’s mood. When Floragato is prepared to\nbattle, its fur becomes pointed and needle sharp.
This Pokémon uses the reflective fur lining its\ncape to camouflage the stem of its flower,\ncreating the illusion that the flower is floating.
With skillful misdirection, it rigs foes with pollen-\npacked flower bombs. Meowscarada sets off the\nbombs before its foes realize what’s going on.
It lies on warm rocks and uses the heat absorbed\nby its square-shaped scales to create fire energy.
Its flame sac is small, so energy is always leaking\nout. This energy is released from the dent atop\nFuecoco’s head and flickers to and fro.
The combination of Crocalor’s fire energy and\noverflowing vitality has caused an egg-shaped\nfireball to appear on the Pokémon’s head.
The valve in Crocalor’s flame sac is closely\nconnected to its vocal cords. This Pokémon utters\na guttural cry as it spews flames every which way.
The fiery bird changes shape when Skeledirge\nsings. Rumor has it that the bird was born when\nthe fireball on Skeledirge’s head gained a soul.
Skeledirge’s gentle singing soothes the souls of\nall that hear it. It burns its enemies to a crisp\nwith flames of over 5,400 degrees Fahrenheit.
This Pokémon migrated to Paldea from distant\nlands long ago. The gel secreted by its feathers\nrepels water and grime.
Its strong legs let it easily swim around in even\nfast-flowing rivers. It likes to keep things tidy and\nis prone to overthinking things.
These Pokémon constantly run through shallow\nwaters to train their legs, then compete with each\nother to see which of them kicks most gracefully.
The hardworking Quaxwell observes people and\nPokémon from various regions and incorporates\ntheir movements into its own dance routines.
A single kick from a Quaquaval can send a truck\nrolling. This Pokémon uses its powerful legs to\nperform striking dances from far-off lands.
Dancing in ways that evoke far-away places, this\nPokémon mesmerizes all that see it. Flourishes of\nits decorative water feathers slice into its foes.
It searches for food all day. It possesses a keen\nsense of smell but doesn’t use it for anything\nother than foraging.
This Pokémon spurns all but the finest of foods.\nIts body gives off an herblike scent that bug\nPokémon detest.
Oinkologne is proud of its fine, glossy skin.\nIt emits a concentrated scent from the tip of\nits tail.
It entrances female Pokémon with the sweet,\nalluring scent that wafts from all over its body.
The ball of threads wrapped around its body is\nelastic enough to deflect the scythes of Scyther,\nthis Pokémon’s natural enemy.
The thread it secretes from its rear is as strong as\nwire. The secret behind the thread’s strength is\nthe topic of ongoing research.
It clings to branches and ceilings using its\nthreads and moves without a sound. It takes\nout its prey before the prey even notices it.
Spidops covers its territory in tough, sticky\nthreads to set up traps for intruders.
It has its third set of legs folded up. When it’s in\na tough spot, this Pokémon jumps over 30 feet\nusing the strength of its legs.
It’s highly skilled at a fighting style in which it\nuses its jumping capabilities to dodge incoming\nattacks while also dealing damage to opponents.
When it decides to fight all out, it stands on its\npreviously folded legs to enter Showdown Mode.\nIt neutralizes its enemies in short order.
It uses its normally folded third set of legs when\nin Showdown Mode. This places a huge burden\non its body, so it can’t stay in this mode for long.
It has underdeveloped electric sacs on its cheeks.\nThese sacs can produce electricity only if Pawmi\nrubs them furiously with the pads on its forepaws.
The pads of its paws are electricity-discharging\norgans. Pawmi fires electricity from its forepaws\nwhile standing unsteadily on its hind legs.
When its group is attacked, Pawmo is the first\nto leap into battle, defeating enemies with a\nfighting technique that utilizes electric shocks.
Pawmo uses a unique fighting technique in which\nit uses its forepaws to strike foes and zap them\nwith electricity from its paw pads simultaneously.
This Pokémon normally is slow to react, but once\nit enters battle, it will strike down its enemies\nwith lightning-fast movements.
Pawmot’s fluffy fur acts as a battery. It can store\nthe same amount of electricity as an electric car.
Exhibiting great teamwork, they use their incisors\nto cut pieces out of any material that might be\nuseful for a nest, then make off with them.
The pair sticks together no matter what. They\nsplit any food they find exactly in half and then\neat it together.
They build huge nests with many rooms that\nare used for different purposes, such as eating\nand sleeping.
The little one just appeared one day. They all\nlive together like a family, but the relationship\nbetween the three is still unclear.
This Pokémon is smooth and moist to the touch.\nYeast in Fidough’s breath induces fermentation in\nthe Pokémon’s vicinity.
The yeast in Fidough’s breath is useful for\ncooking, so this Pokémon has been protected\nby people since long ago.
The pleasant aroma that emanates from this\nPokémon’s body helps wheat grow, so Dachsbun\nhas been treasured by farming villages.
The surface of this Pokémon’s skin hardens\nwhen exposed to intense heat, and its body\nhas an appetizing aroma.
It protects itself from enemies by emitting oil\nfrom the fruit on its head. This oil is bitter and\nastringent enough to make someone flinch.
This Pokémon converts nutrients into oil, which it\nstores in the fruit on its head. It can easily go a\nwhole week without eating or drinking.
Dolliv shares its tasty, fresh-scented oil with\nothers. This species has coexisted with humans\nsince times long gone.
It basks in the sun to its heart’s content until the\nfruits on its head ripen. After that, Dolliv departs\nfrom human settlements and goes on a journey.
This calm Pokémon is very compassionate.\nIt will share its delicious, nutrient-rich oil\nwith weakened Pokémon.
This Pokémon drives back enemies by\nlaunching its rich, aromatic oil at them\nwith enough force to smash a boulder.
These Pokémon prefer to live in cities.\nThey form flocks based on the color of\ntheir feathers, and they fight over territory.
Green-feathered flocks hold the most sway.\nWhen they’re out searching for food in the\nmornings and evenings, it gets very noisy.
It was born in a layer of rock salt deep under the\nearth. This species was particularly treasured in\nthe old days, as they would share precious salt.
The ground scrapes its body as it travels, causing\nit to leave salt behind. Salt is constantly being\ncreated and replenished inside Nacli’s body.
This Pokémon dry cures its prey by spraying salt\nover them. The curing process steals away the\nwater in the prey’s body.
It compresses rock salt inside its body and shoots\nout hardened salt pellets with enough force to\nperforate an iron sheet.
Garganacl will rub its fingertips together and\nsprinkle injured Pokémon with salt. Even severe\nwounds will promptly heal afterward.
Many Pokémon gather around Garganacl,\nhoping to lick at its mineral-rich salt.
Burnt charcoal came to life and became a\nPokémon. Possessing a fiery fighting spirit,\nCharcadet will battle even tough opponents.
Its firepower increases when it fights, reaching\nover 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit. It likes berries\nthat are rich in fat.
Armarouge evolved through the use of a set of\narmor that belonged to a distinguished warrior.\nThis Pokémon is incredibly loyal.
This Pokémon clads itself in armor that has been\nfortified by psychic and fire energy, and it shoots\nblazing fireballs.
The fiery blades on its arms burn fiercely with the\nlingering resentment of a sword wielder who fell\nbefore accomplishing their goal.
An old set of armor steeped in grudges caused\nthis Pokémon’s evolution. Ceruledge cuts its\nenemies to pieces without mercy.
Tadbulb shakes its tail to generate electricity.\nIf it senses danger, it will make its head blink on\nand off to alert its allies.
It floats using the electricity stored in its body.\nWhen thunderclouds are around, Tadbulb will\nfloat higher off the ground.
When this Pokémon expands and contracts its\nwobbly body, the belly-button dynamo in its\nstomach produces a huge amount of electricity.
What appear to be eyeballs are actually organs\nfor discharging the electricity generated by\nBellibolt’s belly-button dynamo.
When its wings catch the wind, the bones within\nproduce electricity. This Pokémon dives into the\nocean, catching prey by electrocuting them.
These Pokémon make their nests on coastal\ncliffs. The nests have a strange, crackling\ntexture, and they’re a popular delicacy.
Kilowattrel inflates its throat sac to amplify its\nelectricity. By riding the wind, this Pokémon can\nfly over 430 miles in a day.
It uses its throat sac to store electricity\ngenerated by its wings. There’s hardly any\noil in its feathers, so it is a poor swimmer.
It always scowls in an attempt to make opponents\ntake it seriously, but even crying children will\nburst into laughter when they see Maschiff’s face.
Its well-developed jaw and fangs are strong\nenough to crunch through boulders, and its thick\nfat makes for an excellent defense.
This Pokémon can store energy in its large\ndewlap. Mabosstiff unleashes this energy all\nat once to blow away enemies.
Mabosstiff loves playing with children. Though\nusually gentle, it takes on an intimidating look\nwhen protecting its family.
Though usually a mellow Pokémon, it will sink its\nsharp, poison-soaked front teeth into any that\nanger it, causing paralysis in the object of its ire.
To keep enemies away from its territory, it paints\nmarkings around its nest using a poisonous liquid\nthat has an acrid odor.
The color of the poisonous saliva depends on\nwhat the Pokémon eats. Grafaiai covers its fingers\nin its saliva and draws patterns on trees in forests.
Each Grafaiai paints its own individual pattern,\nand it will paint that same pattern over and over\nagain throughout its life.
A soul unable to move on to the afterlife was\nblown around by the wind until it got tangled\nup with dried grass and became a Pokémon.
Not even Bramblin knows where it is headed as\nit tumbles across the wilderness, blown by the\nwind. It loathes getting wet.
It will open the branches of its head to envelop\nits prey. Once it absorbs all the life energy it\nneeds, it expels the prey and discards it.
Brambleghast wanders around arid regions.\nOn rare occasions, mass outbreaks of these\nPokémon will bury an entire town.
Toedscool lives in muggy forests. The flaps that\nfall from its body are chewy and very delicious.
Though it looks like Tentacool, Toedscool is a\ncompletely different species. Its legs may be thin,\nbut it can run at a speed of 30 mph.
These Pokémon gather into groups and form\ncolonies deep within forests. They absolutely\nhate it when strangers approach.
It coils its 10 tentacles around prey and sucks out\ntheir nutrients, causing the prey pain. The folds\nalong the rim of its head are a popular delicacy.
Klawf hangs upside-down from cliffs, waiting\nfor prey. But Klawf can’t remain in this position\nfor long because its blood rushes to its head.
This Pokémon lives on sheer cliffs.\nIt sidesteps opponents’ attacks, then\nlunges for their weak spots with its claws.
The more sunlight this Pokémon bathes in, the\nmore spicy chemicals are produced by its body,\nand thus the spicier its moves become.
Traditional Paldean dishes can be extremely spicy\nbecause they include the shed front teeth of\nCapsakid among their ingredients.
The red head converts spicy chemicals into fire\nenergy and blasts the surrounding area with a\nsuper spicy stream of flame.
The green head has turned vicious due to the\nspicy chemicals stimulating its brain. Once it goes\non a rampage, there is no stopping it.
This Pokémon creates a mud ball by mixing\nsand and dirt with psychic energy. It treasures\nits mud ball more than its own life.
It rolls its mud ball around while the energy it\nneeds for evolution matures. Eventually the\ntime comes for it to evolve.
