The body that supports the ball barely moves.\nTherefore, it is thought that the true body of this\nPokémon is actually inside the ball.
An infant sleeps inside the ball. Rabsca rolls\nthe ball soothingly with its legs to ensure the\ninfant sleeps comfortably.
Flittle’s toes levitate about half an inch above\nthe ground because of the psychic power\nemitted from the frills on the Pokémon’s belly.
It spends its time running around wastelands.\nIf anyone steals its beloved berries, it will chase\nthem down and exact its revenge.
It immobilizes opponents by bathing them in\npsychic power from its large eyes. Despite its\nappearance, it has a vicious temperament.
It emits psychic power from the gaps between its\nmulticolored frills and sprints at speeds greater\nthan 120 mph.
It swings its handmade hammer around to protect\nitself, but the hammer is often stolen by Pokémon\nthat eat metal.
This Pokémon pounds iron scraps together to\nmake a hammer. It will remake the hammer again\nand again until it’s satisfied with the result.
This Pokémon will attack groups of Pawniard and\nBisharp, gathering metal from them in order to\ncreate a large and sturdy hammer.
These Pokémon make their homes in piles of\nscrap metal. They test the strength of each\nother’s hammers by smashing them together.
This intelligent Pokémon has a very daring\ndisposition. It knocks rocks into the sky with\nits hammer, aiming for flying Corviknight.
The hammer tops 220 pounds, yet it gets swung\naround easily by Tinkaton as it steals whatever it\npleases and carries its plunder back home.
This Pokémon can pick up the scent of a Veluza\njust over 65 feet away and will hide itself in\nthe sand.
Though it looks like Diglett, Wiglett is an entirely\ndifferent species. The resemblance seems to be a\ncoincidental result of environmental adaptation.
It has a vicious temperament, contrary to what its\nappearance may suggest. It wraps its long bodies\naround prey, then drags the prey into its den.
A variety of fish Pokémon, Wugtrio was\nonce considered to be a regional form\nof Dugtrio.
It gathers things up in an apron made from shed\nfeathers added to the Pokémon’s chest feathers,\nthen drops those things from high places for fun.
Bombirdier uses the apron on its chest to\nbundle up food, which it carries back to its nest.\nIt enjoys dropping things that make loud noises.
It likes playing with others of its kind using the\nwater ring on its tail. It uses ultrasonic waves to\nsense the emotions of other living creatures.
Its water ring is made from seawater mixed with\na sticky fluid that Finizen secretes from\nits blowhole.
This Pokémon changes its appearance if it hears\nits allies calling for help. Palafin will never show\nanybody its moment of transformation.
Its physical capabilities are no different than\na Finizen’s, but when its allies are in danger,\nit transforms and powers itself up.
It is said that this Pokémon was born when an\nunknown poison Pokémon entered and inspirited\nan engine left at a scrap-processing factory.
The steel section is Varoom’s actual body.\nThis Pokémon clings to rocks and converts the\nminerals within into energy to fuel its activities.
It creates a gas out of poison and minerals from\nrocks. It then detonates the gas in its cylinders—\nnow numbering eight—to generate energy.
Revavroom viciously threatens others with the\nsound of its exhaust. It sticks its tongue out from\nits cylindrical mouth and sprays toxic fluids.
Apparently Cyclizar has been allowing people to\nride on its back since ancient times. Depictions of\nthis have been found in 10,000-year-old murals.
It can sprint at over 70 mph while carrying a\nhuman. The rider’s body heat warms Cyclizar’s\nback and lifts the Pokémon’s spirit.
When attacked, this Pokémon will wield\nthe tendrils on its body like fists and pelt\nthe opponent with a storm of punches.
This Pokémon lives in arid deserts.\nIt maintains its metal body by consuming\niron from the soil.
It absorbs nutrients from cave walls. The petals\nit wears are made of crystallized poison.
Glimmet’s toxic mineral crystals look just like\nflower petals. This Pokémon scatters poisonous\npowder like pollen to protect itself.
When this Pokémon detects danger, it will open\nup its crystalline petals and fire beams from its\nconical body.
Glimmora’s petals are made of crystallized\npoison energy. It has recently become evident\nthat these petals resemble Tera Jewels.
It is said that a dog Pokémon that died in the\nwild without ever interacting with a human was\nreborn as this Pokémon.
This friendly Pokémon doesn’t like being alone.\nPay it even the slightest bit of attention, and it\nwill follow you forever.
Houndstone spends most of its time sleeping\nin graveyards. Among all the dog Pokémon,\nthis one is most loyal to its master.
A lovingly mourned Pokémon was reborn as\nHoundstone. It doesn’t like anyone touching\nthe protuberance atop its head.
This Pokémon apparently ties the base of its neck\ninto a knot so that energy stored in its belly does\nnot escape from its beak.
Thanks to a behavior of theirs known as\n“synchronizing,” an entire flock of these Pokémon\ncan attack simultaneously in perfect harmony.
This species left the ocean and began living\non land a very long time ago. It seems to be\nclosely related to Wailmer.
It lives in frigid regions in pods of five or so\nindividuals. It loves the minerals found in snow\nand ice.
This Pokémon wanders around snowy,\nicy areas. It protects its body with powerful\nmuscles and a thick layer of fat under its skin.
Ice energy builds up in the horn on its\nupper jaw, causing the horn to reach cryogenic\ntemperatures that freeze its surroundings.
When Veluza discards unnecessary flesh, its mind\nbecomes honed and its psychic power increases.\nThe spare flesh has a mild but delicious flavor.
Veluza has excellent regenerative capabilities.\nIt sheds spare flesh from its body to boost its\nagility, then charges at its prey.
This Pokémon is a glutton, but it’s bad at\ngetting food. It teams up with a Tatsugiri\nto catch prey.
It treats Tatsugiri like its boss and follows\nit loyally. Though powerful, Dondozo is\napparently not very smart.
This is a small dragon Pokémon. It lives inside the\nmouth of Dondozo to protect itself from enemies\non the outside.
Tatsugiri is an extremely cunning Pokémon.\nIt feigns weakness to lure in prey, then orders\nits partner to attack.
When its anger rose beyond a critical point,\nthis Pokémon gained power that is unfettered\nby the limits of its physical body.
It imbues its fists with the power of the rage that\nit kept hidden in its heart. Opponents struck by\nthese imbued fists will be shattered to their core.
When attacked, this Pokémon will retaliate\nby sticking thick spines out from its body. It’s\na risky move that puts everything on the line.
It lives at the bottom of ponds and swamps.\nIt will carry Wooper on its back and ferry\nthem across water from one shore to the other.
Now that the brain waves from the head and\ntail are synced up, the psychic power of this\nPokémon is 10 times stronger than Girafarig’s.
The hardened head from the tail protects the\nhead of the main body as Farigiraf whips its long\nneck around to headbutt enemies.
This Pokémon uses its hard tail to make its nest\nby boring holes into bedrock deep underground.\nThe nest can reach lengths of over six miles.
It drives enemies out of its nest by sucking\nin enough air to fill its long, narrow lungs,\nthen releasing the air in an intense blast.
Only a Bisharp that stands above all others in\nits vast army can evolve into Kingambit.
Though it commands a massive army in battle,\nit’s not skilled at devising complex strategies.\nIt just uses brute strength to keep pushing.
Sightings of this Pokémon have occurred\nin recent years. The name Great Tusk was\ntaken from a creature listed in a certain book.
This creature resembles a mysterious\nPokémon that, according to a paranormal\nmagazine, has lived since ancient times.
There has been only one reported sighting of this\nPokémon. It resembles a mysterious creature\ndepicted in an old expedition journal.
It resembles a mysterious Pokémon described\nin a paranormal magazine as a Jigglypuff from\none billion years ago.
It is possible that the creature listed as\nBrute Bonnet in a certain book could\nactually be this Pokémon.
It bears a slight resemblance to a Pokémon\ndescribed in a dubious magazine as a cross\nbetween a dinosaur and a mushroom.
This Pokémon has characteristics similar to those\nof Flutter Mane, a creature mentioned in a\ncertain book.
It has similar features to a ghostly pterosaur that\nwas covered in a paranormal magazine, but the\ntwo have little else in common.
This mysterious Pokémon has some similarities\nto a creature that an old book introduced as\nSlither Wing.
This Pokémon somewhat resembles an ancient\nform of Volcarona that was introduced in a\ndubious magazine.
No records exist of this Pokémon being caught.\nData is lacking, but the Pokémon’s traits match\nup with a creature shown in an expedition journal.
It slightly resembles a Magneton that lived for\n10,000 years and was featured in an article in\na paranormal magazine.
This Pokémon closely resembles a scientific\nweapon that a paranormal magazine claimed\nwas sent to this planet by aliens.
Sightings of this Pokémon have occurred in\nrecent years. It resembles a mysterious object\ndescribed in an old expedition journal.
Its shape is similar to a robot featured in a\nparanormal magazine article. The robot was said\nto have been created by an ancient civilization.
It resembles a mysterious object mentioned in an\nold book. There are only two reported sightings\nof this Pokémon.
It is very similar to a cyborg covered exclusively\nby a paranormal magazine. The cyborg was said\nto be the modified form of a certain athlete.
This Pokémon shares many similarities\nwith Iron Hands, an object mentioned in\na certain expedition journal.
It resembles a certain Pokémon introduced in a\nparanormal magazine, described as the offspring\nof a Hydreigon that fell in love with a robot.
It’s possible that Iron Jugulis, an object\ndescribed in an old book, may actually\nbe this Pokémon.
This Pokémon resembles an unknown object\ndescribed in a paranormal magazine as a UFO\nsent to observe humanity.
No records exist of this species being caught.\nData is lacking, but the Pokémon’s traits match\nup with an object described in an old book.
It has some similarities to a Pokémon introduced\nin a dubious magazine as a Tyranitar from one\nbillion years into the future.
Some of its notable features match those of an\nobject named within a certain expedition journal\nas Iron Thorns.
Frigibax absorbs heat through its dorsal fin and\nconverts the heat into ice energy. The higher the\ntemperature, the more energy Frigibax stores.
This Pokémon lives in forests and craggy areas.\nUsing the power of its dorsal fin, it cools the\ninside of its nest like a refrigerator.
Arctibax freezes the air around it, protecting its\nface with an ice mask and turning its dorsal fin\ninto a blade of ice.
It attacks with the blade of its frozen dorsal fin\nby doing a front flip in the air. Arctibax’s strong\nback and legs allow it to pull off this technique.
This Pokémon blasts cryogenic air out from\nits mouth. This air can instantly freeze even\nliquid-hot lava.
It launches itself into battle by flipping upside\ndown and spewing frigid air from its mouth.\nIt finishes opponents off with its dorsal blade.
This Pokémon was born inside a treasure chest\nabout 1,500 years ago. It sucks the life-force\nout of scoundrels who try to steal the treasure.
It lives inside an old treasure chest. Sometimes it\ngets left in shop corners since no one realizes\nit’s actually a Pokémon.
Its body seems to be made up of 1,000 coins.\nThis Pokémon gets along well with others and is\nquick to make friends with anybody.
It has a sturdy body made up of stacked coins.\nGholdengo overwhelms its enemies by firing coin\nafter coin at them in quick succession.
The grudge of a person punished for writing the\nking’s evil deeds upon wooden tablets has clad\nitself in dead leaves to become a Pokémon.
It drains the life-force from vegetation, causing\nnearby forests to instantly wither and fields to\nturn barren.
This Pokémon can control 100 tons of\nfallen snow. It plays around innocently by\nleaping in and out of avalanches it has caused.
The hatred of those who perished by the\nsword long ago has clad itself in snow\nand become a Pokémon.
The fear poured into an ancient ritual vessel\nhas clad itself in rocks and dirt to become\na Pokémon.
It slowly brings its exceedingly heavy head down\nupon the ground, splitting the earth open with\nhuge fissures that run over 160 feet deep.
It controls flames burning at over 5,400 degrees\nFahrenheit. It casually swims through the sea of\nlava it creates by melting rock and sand.
The envy accumulated within curved beads that\nsparked multiple conflicts has clad itself in fire\nand become a Pokémon.
It is possible that this is the creature\nlisted as Roaring Moon in an expedition\njournal that still holds many mysteries.
According to an article in a dubious magazine,\nthis Pokémon has some connection to a\nphenomenon that occurs in a certain region.
It has some similarities to a mad scientist’s\ninvention covered in a paranormal magazine.
It’s possible that this is the object listed as\nIron Valiant in a certain expedition journal.
This seems to be the Winged King mentioned\nin an old expedition journal. It was said to have\nsplit the land with its bare fists.
This Pokémon resembles Cyclizar, but it is far\nburlier and more ferocious. Nothing is known\nabout its ecology or other features.
Much remains unknown about this\ncreature. It resembles Cyclizar, but it\nis far more ruthless and powerful.
This seems to be the Iron Serpent mentioned\nin an old book. The Iron Serpent is said to have\nturned the land to ash with its lightning.
This ferocious creature is shrouded in mystery.\nIt’s named after an aquatic monster mentioned\nin an old expedition journal.
It resembles an illustration published in a\nparanormal magazine, said to be a depiction\nof a super-ancient Suicune.
Many of its physical characteristics match those\nof a Virizion from the future that was covered in\na paranormal magazine.
According to the few eyewitness accounts that\nexist, it used its shining blades to julienne large\ntrees and boulders.
Dipplin is two creatures in one Pokémon.\nIts evolution was triggered by a special apple\ngrown only in one place.
The head sticking out belongs to the fore-wyrm,\nwhile the tail belongs to the core-wyrm. The two\nshare one apple and help each other out.
Supposedly, the regrets of a tea ceremony master\nwho died before perfecting his craft lingered in\nsome matcha and became a Pokémon.
Poltchageist looks like a regional form of\nSinistea, but it was recently discovered that\nthe two Pokémon are entirely unrelated.
It pretends to be tea, trying to fool people into\ndrinking it so it can drain their life-force. Its ruse\nis generally unsuccessful.
It prefers cool, dark places, such as the back of a\nshelf or the space beneath a home’s floorboards.\nIt wanders in search of prey after sunset.
After all its muscles were stimulated by\nthe toxic chain around its neck, Okidogi\ntransformed and gained a powerful physique.
Okidogi is a ruffian with a short temper.\nIt can pulverize anything by swinging\naround the chain on its neck.
The chain is made from toxins that enhance\ncapabilities. It stimulated Munkidori’s brain and\ncaused the Pokémon’s psychic powers to bloom.
Munkidori keeps itself somewhere safe while it\ntoys with its foes, using psychokinesis to induce\nintense dizziness.
Fezandipiti owes its beautiful looks and lovely\nvoice to the toxic stimulants emanating from the\nchain wrapped around its body.
Fezandipiti beats its glossy wings to scatter\npheromones that captivate people and Pokémon.
This Pokémon’s type changes based on which\nmask it’s wearing. It confounds its enemies with\nnimble movements and kicks.
This mischief-loving Pokémon is full of curiosity.\nIt battles by drawing out the type-based energy\ncontained within its masks.
It gathers static electricity from its surroundings.\nThe beams it launches when down on all fours\nare tremendously powerful.
It digs holes on mountains, searching for food.\nIt’s so durable that being caught in a cave-in\nwon’t faze it.
Seven syrpents live inside an apple made\nof syrup. The syrpent in the center is the\ncommander.
These capricious syrpents have banded together.\nOn the rare occasion that their moods align,\ntheir true power is unleashed.
There are scant few reports of this creature\nbeing sighted. One short video shows it\nrampaging and spouting pillars of flame.
It resembles an eerie Pokémon once shown in a\nparanormal magazine. That Pokémon was said to\nbe an Entei regenerated from a fossil.
It’s said to incinerate everything around it with\nlightning launched from its fur. Very little is\nknown about this creature.
It bears resemblance to a Pokémon that became\na hot topic for a short while after a paranormal\nmagazine touted it as Raikou’s ancestor.
It resembles a Pokémon described in a\ndubious magazine as a Terrakion that had\nbeen modified by an evil organization.
It was named after a mysterious object\nrecorded in an old book. Its body seems\nto be metallic.
It resembles a mysterious object introduced in a\nparanormal magazine as a cutting-edge weapon\nshaped like a Cobalion.
There was supposedly an incident in which it\nlaunched shining blades to cut everything around\nit to pieces. Little else is known about it.
Terapagos protects itself using its power to\ntransform energy into hard crystals. This Pokémon\nis the source of the Terastal phenomenon.
It’s thought that this Pokémon lived in ancient\nPaldea until it got caught in seismic shifts and\nwent extinct.
It feeds others toxic mochi that draw out desires\nand capabilities. Those who eat the mochi fall\nunder Pecharunt’s control, chained to its will.
Its peach-shaped shell serves as storage for\na potent poison. It makes poisonous mochi\nand serves them to people and Pokémon.
If the convection microwave oven is not working\nproperly, then the Rotom inhabiting it will\nbecome lethargic.
This Rotom has possessed a convection\nmicrowave oven. It will sear the surrounding\narea with its burning heat, then smile in delight.
This Rotom has entered a washing machine.\nIt nods with satisfaction after it floods the\nsurrounding area.
The model of washing machine that Rotom\ncan inspirit has been discontinued, so these\nappliances are now traded at high prices.
This Rotom has entered a refrigerator. It leaps\naround gleefully after it uses cold air to freeze\nthe area around it.
The special motor within the refrigerator is the\nkey to bringing about Rotom’s change in form.
This Rotom has entered an electric fan. It smirks\nwith satisfaction over a prank well pulled after it\nblows away everything around it.
There are several appliances that Rotom can\ninspirit, but the first one to be developed was\nthe electric fan.
The lawn mower is one of the household\nappliances that led to the development of\nthe Rotom Dex.
This Rotom has possessed a lawn mower. It will\nmow down grass and flowers, then swagger\naround with pride at its accomplishments.
These Pokémon form schools with others of the\nsame color. The greatest foe of a school of blue\nBasculin is a school of red Basculin.
The power of its jaws is immense—enough to\nleave teeth marks in iron sheets. Its personality\nis also extremely vicious.
Female Meowstic are more aggressive than\nmales. Their expression remains blank even\nwhile they’re wielding immense psychic power.
When they sense danger, they exert their psychic\npower at its maximum output. They have no\nregard for their opponents.
The cap this Pikachu wears is filled with memories\nof this Pokémon and its partner traveling across\nlots of different regions together.
This Pikachu wears its partner’s cap—proof of\nthe strong bond Pikachu and its partner formed\nduring adventures across many different regions.
It lives on snowy mountains. Its steel shell is\nvery hard—so much so, it can’t roll its body up\ninto a ball.
An ancient tradition of Alolan festivals, still\ncarried on to this day, is a competition to slide\nSandshrew across ice as far as one can.
This Pokémon’s steel spikes are sheathed\nin ice. Stabs from these spikes cause deep\nwounds and severe frostbite as well.
A long, long time ago, it lived in the desert.\nWith its sharp claws fully extended, it can run\nright up an iceberg without slipping.
They live together in a skulk, helping one another.\nBefore eating their prey, they freeze it solid with\ntheir −58 degree Fahrenheit breath.
In hot weather, this Pokémon makes ice shards\nwith its six tails and sprays them around to cool\nitself off.
Possessing a calm demeanor, this Pokémon was\nrevered as a deity incarnate before it was\nidentified as a regional variant of Ninetales.
It creates drops of ice in its coat and showers\nthem over its enemies. Anyone who angers it will\nbe frozen stiff in an instant.
The things growing from its head are whiskers\nthat have become metallic. Diglett communicates\nwith its comrades by waving them.
Its golden whiskers function as sensors.\nIt pokes them out of its burrow to monitor\nits surroundings.
Its shining gold whiskers are advanced sensors\nthat can detect vibrations from sounds several\nmiles away.
Its metallic whiskers are heavy, so it’s not very\nfast, but it has the power to dig through even\nthe hardest bedrock.
Its body is a magnetic stone. Iron sand attaches\nfirmly to the portions of its body that are\nparticularly magnetic.
If you step on a Geodude sleeping on the\nground, you’ll hear a zapping sound and feel\na tingling shock throughout your entire body.
They eat rocks and often get into a scrap over\nthem. The impact of Graveler smashing together\ncauses a flash of light and a booming noise.
Graveler’s entire body is electrically charged\ndue to the stones it likes to eat. It is a very\nquick-tempered Pokémon.
It’s grumpy and stubborn. If you upset it, it\ndischarges electricity from the surface of its\nbody and growls with a voice like thunder.
It fires rocks charged with electricity. Even if the\nrock isn’t fired that accurately, just grazing an\nopponent will cause numbness and fainting.
They store their toxins inside their bodies, so\nunlike Grimer from other regions, they don’t\nsmell bad even up close.
Alolan Grimer will gladly gobble up any kind\nof trash, making it a widely used and popular\nPokémon at garbage disposal facilities.
There are over a hundred kinds of poison\ninside its body. Chemical reactions between\ndifferent poisons are the source of its vitality.
What look like fangs and claws are actually\ncrystallized poison that will afflict you at a\nmere touch, so don’t get too close.
It swings its long neck like a whip and smacks its\nhead into opponents. This makes Exeggutor itself\na little dizzy too.
As it grew taller and taller, it outgrew its reliance\non psychic powers, while within it awakened the\npower of the sleeping dragon.
This form of Oricorio has sipped yellow nectar.\nIt uses nimble steps to approach opponents,\nthen knocks them out with electric punches.
The energetic, cheerful dance of these Oricorio\nis popular with children, but the Oricorio\nthemselves are hard to find in Paldea.
The airy dance of these Oricorio is popular as\na means of maintaining good health, but the\nOricorio themselves are hard to find in Paldea.
This form of Oricorio has sipped pink nectar.\nIt elevates its mind with the gentle steps of its\ndance, then unleashes its psychic energy.
This form of Oricorio has sipped purple nectar.\nIt uses ethereal dance steps to call forth the\nspirits of the dead.
The elegant, attractive dance of these Oricorio is\npopular with adults, but the Oricorio themselves\nare hard to find in Paldea.
This Pokémon uses its rocky mane to slash any\nwho approach. It will even disobey its Trainer\nif it dislikes the orders it was given.
This Lycanroc has an extremely vicious\ntemperament. It will happily sustain injuries\nfor the sake of taking down its opponent.
Minior that fall to the ground try to return to\nspace, but their wish will not come true—all they\ncan do is fade away.
It feeds on dust in the atmosphere. The color\nof its core is said to be determined by the\ncomposition of the dust it eats.
Normally this Pokémon doesn’t even bark, but\nonce it enters battle, it will relentlessly drive the\nopponent into a corner.
These Pokémon have both calm and ferocious\nqualities. It’s said that this form of Lycanroc is\nthe most troublesome to raise.
Many youths admire the way this Pokémon\nlistlessly picks fights and keeps its cool no\nmatter what opponent it faces.
As it gulps down stagnant water and generates\nelectricity in its body, a sound like a rhythm\nplayed by a bass guitar reverberates all around.
The ice that was covering this Eiscue’s face has\nshattered. Eiscue emits cold air from the tip of its\nhair to protect its head, which is sensitive to heat.
Contrary to its looks, Eiscue is a poor swimmer.\nIt creates ice balls at the tip of its single hair to\nlure prey in and fish them up.
It dislikes conflict. If a fight occurs in its territory,\nit uses psychic power to throw things at the\ncombatants in an effort to drive them away.
In search of happy feelings—such as joy and\ngratitude—Indeedee bustles around, taking\ndiligent care of people and other Pokémon.
It gives off a stimulating scent because of\nchemicals that have seeped into its body from\nthe spice that it eats as its staple food.
It uses its tail to fish, but the scent of the spice\nemanating from its tail ensures its catches are\nalways lacking.
Shellder seems blissful over the taste of Slowbro\neven though the toxins seeping from the bite\nhave caused Shellder to faint.
Shellder bites down hard on Slowbro’s arm\nto suck out more poison. This seems to cause\nitching, so Slowbro occasionally lashes out.
It administers its potions to weakened Pokémon\nit sees. These potions are derived from poison\nand secreted from holes in Slowking’s horns.
It creates potions by mixing toxins with the food\nit’s eaten. Not even Slowking itself knows what\neffects the potions will have.
It lives just offshore in cold parts of the world.\nIts poisonous spikes are thicker and shorter than\nthose of other regions’ Qwilfish.
It absorbs toxins from the food it eats.\nThe distinct purple spikes on its body are\nevidence of its potent poison.
They live in frigid seas, forming schools and\nsharing food among themselves. When the time\ncomes, they return to the river they were born in.
Its ecology is starkly different from that of other\nBasculin, so theories that it’s a totally different\nspecies have gained traction in recent years.
The souls of its comrades cloak its body and\npropel it effortlessly through even raging rapids.
It can afflict a target with terrifying illusions that\nare under its control. The deeper the sadness in\nits friends’ souls, the paler Basculegion becomes.
This Pokémon has a muscular body and excels at\nclose-quarters combat. It uses its short horns to\nstrike the opponent’s weak spots.
This kind of Tauros, known as the Combat Breed,\nis distinguished by its thick, powerful muscles and\nits fierce disposition.
When heated by fire energy, its horns can get\nhotter than 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit. Those\ngored by them will suffer both wounds and burns.
People call this kind of Tauros the Blaze Breed\ndue to the hot air it snorts from its nostrils.\nIts three tails are intertwined.
This Pokémon blasts water from holes on the\ntips of its horns—the high-pressure jets pierce\nright through Tauros’s enemies.
It swims by jetting water from its horns. The\nmost notable characteristic of the Aqua Breed\nis its high body fat, which allows it to float easily.
After losing a territorial struggle, Wooper began\nliving on land. The Pokémon changed over time,\ndeveloping a poisonous film to protect its body.
It’s dangerous for Wooper to travel alone. They\nline up in groups of three or four and help each\nother as they walk around the wetlands.
This Pokémon sends a flowerlike scent wafting\nabout. Well-developed muscles in its legs allow it\nto leap more than 16 feet with no trouble at all.
This is a meticulous Pokémon that likes to keep\nthings tidy. It shrouds itself in a floral aroma that\nsoothes the Pokémon around it.
The largest of their flocks can contain more\nthan 50 individuals. They fly around towns and\nforests, searching for food and making a racket.
Blue-feathered Squawkabilly view their green-\nfeathered counterparts as rivals, since the latter\nmake up the largest, most powerful groups.
These Squawkabilly are hotheaded, and their\nfighting style is vicious. They’ll leap within reach\nof their foes to engage in close combat.
The yellow Squawkabilly are especially fierce.\nThey’ve even been known to drive other bird\nPokémon out of town.
This Pokémon dislikes being alone. It has a\nstrong sense of community and survives by\ncooperating with allies.
Though these Squawkabilly are the fewest in\nnumber, they have no trouble living in towns\nsince they blend in with the white buildings.
This Pokémon’s ancient genes have awakened.\nIt is now so extraordinarily strong that it can\neasily lift a cruise ship with one fin.
This hero of the ocean swims at a speed of 50\nknots and saves drowning people and Pokémon.
This Pokémon was born from passion that seeped\ninto a coin. It wanders, apparently seeking to\nreturn to the treasure chest it once inhabited.
It wanders around, carrying an old coin on its\nback. It survives by draining the life-force from\nhumans who try to pick up its coin.
It crossed the sea and drifted ashore in a new\nland. Surviving in this place led it to take on a\nunique appearance and gain special powers.
This special Ursaluna can see in the dark with\nits left eye and protects itself with mud that is\nas hard as iron.
This form excels in both attack and defense.\nIt ceaselessly unleashes moves like a spring\ngushes water.
In this form, it draws on the power of water.\nIt attacks unrelentingly with kicks and ivy strikes.
This form is the most aggressive, bombarding\nenemies with the intensity of flames blazing\nwithin a hearth.
In this form, it draws on the power of fire.\nIt spears its enemies with thorn-covered ivy.
This form has excellent defenses, absorbing\nimpacts solidly like the cornerstones that support\nhouses.
In this form, it draws on the power of stone.\nIts body is rock-solid, protecting it from all\nmanner of attacks.
Upon sensing danger, it prepares itself for\nbattle by creating a sturdy shell of crystallized\nTerastal energy.
The shell is made of crystallized Terastal energy.\nWhen struck by a move, this shell absorbs the\nmove’s energy and transfers it to Terapagos.
In this form, Terapagos resembles the world\nas the ancients saw it, and its Terastal energy\nis abnormally amplified.
An old expedition journal describes the sight of\nthis Pokémon buried in the depths of the earth as\nresembling a planet floating in space.
A recently published research paper states that\nthis form of Shellos is gradually decreasing\nin number.
This Pokémon can often be seen along seashores.\nIt’s capable of spending a limited amount of time\non land.
They normally inhabit rocky seashores, but in\ntimes of continuous rain, they can sometimes be\nfound in the mountains, far from the sea.
Fishers say that they didn’t see many of these\nPokémon in the past, but this form of Gastrodon\nis now increasing in number.
To prevent Deerling from entering their fields,\nmany farmers will have several Lycanroc stand\nguard, as they are the natural enemy of Deerling.
Deerling have different scents depending on the\nseason. When a distinct grassy smell starts to waft\nfrom one, you know that summer has begun.
These Pokémon are not shy—they will behave as\nthey please, even in front of people. If you feed\none of them, it will quickly take a liking to you.
Deerling have different scents depending on the\nseason. In this form, Deerling have a softly sweet\nscent that lingers in the nose.
Deerling’s scent changes with the seasons, but\nwhen the Pokémon is in its Winter Form, it has\nhardly any scent at all.
This Pokémon will playfully headbutt those it gets\nalong well with. It has antlers hidden under its\nflower, so the headbutts are a little painful.
There are many Sawsbuck enthusiasts. The thicker\nand larger the branches and leaves on its antlers,\nthe more majestic the Sawsbuck is thought to be.
This Pokémon’s leaves can be made into a black\ntea, the taste of which varies depending on the\nregion of origin. Paldea’s is especially aromatic.
There are many Sawsbuck enthusiasts. The darker\nthe red of the foliage that hangs from its antlers,\nthe more stylish the Sawsbuck is thought to be.
Sawsbuck in their Autumn Form are known for\nhaving very short tempers. The males fight each\nother incessantly.
It’s said that Sawsbuck are calm and easy to tame\nduring the season when they take on this form,\nso it’s the perfect time to make one your partner.
Though there are many enthusiasts for Sawsbuck\nas a species, this seasonal form in particular is\nnot very popular.

This Flabébé rides a yellow flower. The Pokémon\nis defenseless and vulnerable before it has found\nand received power from a flower.
It unleashes a variety of moves by drawing forth\nthe power hidden within flowers. This Pokémon is\nparticularly fond of yellow flowers.
This Flabébé rides an orange flower. On its\nhead, it wears a crown of pollen that has\nhealing properties.
It receives strength from flowers and gives them\nsome of its energy in return. This Pokémon likes\norange flowers best of all.
Once it finds a flower it likes, this Pokémon will\nspend the rest of its life taking care of its flower.\nThis Flabébé rides a blue flower.
This Pokémon likes blue flowers best of all.\nIt floats upward using the power emanating from\nits flower and bobs along lightly through the air.
This Flabébé rides a white flower. The wind\nblows this Pokémon around as it drifts in search\nof flower gardens.
When evening falls, it searches out a place\nblooming with flowers of the same white color\nas itself, and then it goes to sleep.
This Pokémon can draw forth the power hidden\nwithin yellow flowers. This power then becomes\nthe moves Floette uses to protect itself.
Floette can draw forth the latent capabilities of\nGrass-type Pokémon. It syncs with yellow flowers.
This Pokémon can draw forth the most power\nwhen in sync with orange flowers, compared to\nflowers of other colors.
This Pokémon cannot use moves on its own.\nWhen it syncs with flowers, it becomes able\nto use Grass-type moves.
Whenever this Pokémon finds flowering plants\nthat are withering, it will bring them back to its\nterritory and care for them until they are healthy.
It exchanges power with flowers via wavelengths\nof visible light. This form of Floette can sync with\nthe wavelength that produces the color blue.
Floette that are fond of white flowers can also\neasily sync with flowers of other colors.
If it finds someone messing up a flower bed,\nit will attack them without mercy. This Floette\ntakes particularly good care of white flowers.
It is said that there was once a Florges that\nprotected the garden of a castle for over\n300 years.
This Pokémon battles by drawing forth the power\nof yellow flowers. It ruthlessly punishes anyone\nwho tramples on flowering plants.
Its orange flowers fire off powerful beams,\nattacking as if they were a battery of artillery.
In times long past, castle governors would\nlovingly raise Florges to care for their castles’\nexquisite gardens.
Though usually compassionate, Florges will hunt\ndown anyone who vandalizes its flower garden,\nshowing no mercy even if they beg for their lives.
Blue pigments were tremendously expensive\nin the past, so paintings of blue Florges are\nhighly valuable.
A flower garden made by a white-flowered\nFlorges will be beautifully decorated with\nflowering plants of many different colors.
A Florges adorned with white flowers can sync\nwith the wavelengths of various colors to draw\nforth their power.

Minior that fall to the ground try to return to\nspace, but their wish will not come true—all they\ncan do is fade away.
It feeds on dust in the atmosphere. The color\nof its core is said to be determined by the\ncomposition of the dust it eats.
